reviewText:
First of all, I will recommend this game for people who love jet arcade fighting. If you have or like these game (H.A.W.X, H.A.W.X II) you probably will love AC:AH too.
if you really want to play AC, don't read my review afterwards.






I really love Ace Combat since it's first apperance in PS1, and I just can't deny this AC:AH is a dumb-down version from every Ace Combat ever released. to summarize my review, I'll point out the pro & con.

Pro :
+ Graphic are nice and well done, the cockpit view are beast
+ Loading time is good. lol.
+ There's many option for jet, jet color, choice of weapon, in every mission. So you can refining your playstile well.
+ Homing missile mechanic are improved from the latest AC, it's hard enough to avoid it, but didn't make it too hard either. You can do tricks like stall tho.
+ The story a bit interesting, but back again to Russia vs America fairytale.

Con :
- The DFM mode really breakdown this game. here's the problem and why; some enemies (like boss or some red target) can't be taken down by just aiming missile, they must be forced to DFM with you to trigger the scripted storyline. And you will notice it just the same if you repeat the mission, even if you are miles apart from the last DFM happening. (the triggered event like, dogfight beyond the building, or valley, or pipe tower, or else). What's the point with that? you just literally, only control to have your opponent in the crosshair, and your speed. The steering is auto-pilot, LOL!

- Since when your jet can regenerated health?! There's no damage breakdown like any other Ace Combat, what we like is we know if our wing is hit, or our tail-wing is broken and we can feel the downside of it. not just LIGHT DAMAGE, MEDIUM DAMAGE, HEAVY ♥♥♥♥IN DAMAGE, and you can heal up like nothing happened...........

- If you play MGR:R, you'll ♥♥♥♥ yourself knowing the story almost have the same background for the protagonist. So people, if you want to be the hero, let yourself having a PTSD.




Get it on sale! not worth the full price!

reviewText: If you liked Ace Combat in PS2 era, you will hate this game. This is not a dog fight plane sim, this is Call of Duty with wings.

reviewText:
Very bad Controlls, booring and odd Missions:
(I'm sorry for my bad english..)

The controls of this game are really bad. They are made for consoles, not for PC. You can't control the planes with the mouse, you need to use the keyboard bothhanded. It's absolute hateful to play like this. For the helicopters you can use your mouse, but either the mouse is to fast - or to slow to turn the heli around. And the mouse control is very jerky, too. On the other side you have autoaim, but.. wth? No one likes that (on a PC)...
Even other vehicles or weapons are hard and very bad to control.

The settings" should really not been called "settings"
date: you can't change enough.\n\nThe graphics are more or less ok
recommended: but only for the vehicles you fly. For ground based enemies... it reminds me of "C&C Generals"
hoursPlayed: which is now really old - this graphics are bad.\nThere are only really really simple graphics settings available: Brightness
voteText:
V-Sync and Anti-Alaising on/off. Nothing more..

The missions aren't really exciting. There aren't even all in the same context as it seems.
The missions are long

reviewText:
I have always been a huge fan of the Ace Combat series, but this game is a huge let-down.  I will disagree that the DFM system is necessary to take down the Target Leads like many of the other reviews have stated, but the enemy forces the mode far too frequently to be realistic or to make the harder difficulties even remotely enjoyable.

Attempting to bait enemies away from a furball is next to impossible unless they are not a main target.  Main targets remained locked together in a mess on one side of the battlefield and you are forced to go into it to get anything done and that results in constant missile dodging and lock-ons from the enemy and being forced into DFM by two enemies at a time at every moment.  The AI pilots on your side are useless and pretty much never get kills or even assist in combat, unlike in HAWX.  Their only purpose is as a distraction for the enemy and they don't even do that well.

In general, I enjoyed the game up until the obvious betrayal of the Russians.  Many reviewers have said that the storyline is forgettable, but, again, I would have to disagree.  While predictable, the story should interest anyone with a good understanding of military and how warfare is engaged in.  The multiplayer seems to be where this game shines and what it was intended for, because I am completely finding the campaign difficult to enjoy solo.  Perhaps in co-op it would be more fun.

A patch to the AI is definitely necessary to enjoy the campaign in this game.  Fortunately, playing multiplayer seems to feel like a much more realistic combat scenario than the BS you go through in the campaign storyline.  I will still recommend this game to people.  On lower difficulties, the game is fun and worth going through, but since higher difficulties are necessary for some of the unlocks, you won't be able to get everything like that.  Multiplayer will be a rewarding experience all around, though more people need to buy into the game so that there is more population available for multiplayer.

reviewText: I got this game based on positive opinons on the series as a whole. Flying was good, DFM was okay, the turret section was boring, the plot was generic in subject matter and execution, and the helicopter mission's controls and level design were so awful that I stopped playing there.\n\nI don't understand the principle of cashing in and taking inspiration from Call of Duty, because all of the people that like COD are already dedicated to COD. Also, the Ace Combat series has a smaller audience that didn't appreciate the casualization of their series, so reviews and sales weren't good as it failed to appeal to a larger fanbase. Maybe I'll play this again, but it would have to take some real boredom for me to reach down to the bottom of the barrel that is my Steam Library.

reviewText: Well I have a mixed opinion on this particular addition to the frachise. I have always been an avid Ace Combat fan with Ace Combat 6 Fires Of Liberation being my favourite (Xbox 360). Assault Horizon just does not hold the same feeling of fun that ace combat 6 offered. The forced use of dogfights while cool in concept just becomes annoying and less feeling like you are able to fly as you wish like in ace combat 6. Although that being said I still think it worth a play as the game still shines in some areas such as cinematic plane finishers and some dogfights can be pretty intense as the game goes on. Performance wise this game ran flawlessly in full 1920x1080 on a 6GB GTX 980Ti at a locked 144fps (144hz monitor). So no issues with performance.\n\n7/10 All in all worth a try but don't expect it to be like how you have previously experienced the franchise.

reviewText:
Ace Combat Assaut Horizon (ACAH) is air fight simulator, as much as Call of Duty is soldier simulator. While it looks like one, it's made to be a game, not a flight simulator.
Plot? As American pilot, alongside with russians you fight with some rebels. But it's predictable like kid with knife to us that russians will eventually turn against us. The plot twist? Not all of them. Yay.
Ending with plot, ending with sarcasm, I promise. ACAH has some pretty nice mechanics. Most of the time player sees the world from planes' cockpit. Nice thing is, there are plenty of fighters (Not only american!) to choose, each comes with unique cockpit. At the beginning of the mission, player may also choose camo for his fighter. Looks nice when you dont like cockpit sight and preffer to play in Third person camera.  Last camera mode is placed on the fighters'  neb.
Mission objectives? Hm... essential part of every level are fighter fights. If you are playing as fighter, you can be sure that there will be air fight. Besides, pilot might have to perform air strike, protect transporters (by fighting planes) or shooting down a warhead.
Why if? Namco knew that featuring only fighters would be boring, so in certain missions you use different aircraft. So you provide air support as assault chopper pilot (somehow flying in theese make me feel as I were playing some console port - hitting anything without using lock on is really time-consuming), operate minigun in Black Hawk (as for me - best  part of the game), fly AC-130 (copied from CoD, but still awesome) or drop bombs from B-2 Spirit Tactical bomber. Plenty of attractions, aren't there?
Make the metal bleed was the games' motto. I agree on that. Explosions, destroyed fighters and soo many more were awesome. Playing the game for graphics is totally worth it (okay, maybe ground structures could've been done better, but come on, you barely look at the ground!). And all that looked flawlessly on Nvidia GeForce GTS 250 and 4GB of RAM.
To sum up, ACAH was great game. If you like fighters, and modern air combat - don't hesitate.
P.S: No word about multiplayer, because I havent even tried it

reviewText:
This game is one of the worst games you are ever likely to play.

As you can see my time playing the game is very limited, so some may say this is a very cursory assessment of this game. However the reason is quite simple, I'd rather saw my face off with a shard of glass than waste any more time playing this game. Some games deserve a chance to show you their true worth, this game however needed only '0.5 hours' to make me realise what a hugely regrettable mistake I had made.

Basically, the flying mechanices feel like it is Road Rash for the air, although frankly that would be doing a disserivce to Road Rash. But basically, it feels like you are still and the map/environment is coming towards you.

I was interested in a co-op dogfighting simulator and when I bagged this in the sales I thought I was onto a winner, alas this turned out to be utterly fallacious. I quickly realised that the developers must have been cackling all the way to the bank and I had been royally bu##ered with my pants firmly around my ankles.

If you like having your pants pulled down and being royally buggered, this is the game for you!

reviewText:
好吧！关于这篇文章我很早就想写了【原谅我不是主机但不知玩了所有作品】
最初接受这个游戏是PSP上的，玩了一后整个人一发不可收拾，然后接下来就开始追前面几款作品。
第一，此游戏完美的世界设定关是很多飞行游戏都没有的，完美的敌对，以及让人深陷其中无法自拔的主线剧情【超有代感！危机四起】
第二，此游戏的BGM完美无比，无论Boss战，还是攻防战，BGM做的都恰到好处，敌方王牌的介绍简直让你燃到爆
第三，游戏的各种设定虽然不正式，忽略了G加速力以及载挂能力，但是这款游戏却变得更加精彩，甩尾系统，追击系统，以及单挑与反单挑都为这款画质不出色的游戏带来的强大吸引力
第四，多人联机各自的配合，机体与机体的互补，团队合作，以及1V3咬尾无耻战术【hhh】都令人为之畅快。
第五，宿命的对决，每一作，都会有个宿命的敌人【基佬】鲨鱼！zero！都超令人影响深刻。最后的单挑Boss战都是在千百万次虐待中将敌人完美暴机。
第六，你为什么还不快买！官方自带偶像大师皮肤的！身为动漫控以及猥琐大叔的你为什么还入手！！！

I want to like it, but I just can't bring myself to. Being a Huge Ace Combat fan I was hoping to see past the flaws and enjoy the game for what it is. But god damn, is it awful. I thought Ace Combat 6 was the worst Ace game I've played. This takes the cake, bar none. I take it back, Fire of Liberation!

First of all, DFM and Gameplay. I hate DFM. It literally ruins the game for me.
Some targets are quite obviously unkillable UNTIL you engage the DFM. Why? You can tell. Any plane with TGT will pop flares endlessly and go from 0 to 60 in 1 second to avoid your conventional missles. This is obviously to get you to use DFM. To force your plane into an often very scripted chase scene. Sure, it looks fantastic. But after the eye-candy wears off it becomes an object of pure annoyance. It takes the feeling of being a Sky-badass away and makes it into a very boring rollercoaster ride. Sometimes you'll be asked to do quick-time events as well. Press W to see something happen! If you don't press that button..nothing happens 9 times outta 10.
It's completely pointless.

-Second. The missions. Endless waves of very dumb Targets.
Now I have no problem with scores of enemies. In fact I love it when AC does that. But when it involves mostly being forced into the Bogey on Your Six" Mini-game (that's incredibly easy to boot) and DFM it really does become painful. There is little variation between the Red targets they throw at you. No enemy chatter
date: or at least none compelling enough to take note. The whole point of TGT was to make them special targets. Not things you hurtle at the player endlessly like the regular grunts.\nMissions are split between planes
recommended:
helicopters and bombing missions now. I can appreciate the variation but the Bombers and Helo missions are terrible linear crap. Not to mention very boring. Blah. Toss those out.

-Third. Story.
Story isn't the worst thing to this game
hoursPlayed: even though I dislike the real world setting among other things. I will forgive the very typical Modern Warfare-ish plot as well. Don't expect the typical Ace Combat War drama here. It's nothing out of the ordinary.\nThe characters are likable
voteText:
albeit forgettable. I didn't quite like having the protagonist blabbering on while I'm playing but that's more of a personal nuisance.

-Fourth. Difficulty
I can really
helpfulPercent: really tell they lowered the difficulty of this game. I know previous Ace Combats weren't all that hard to begin with (hence the mega-bosses and tunnel missions) but A.H. really drops the bar. Playing on "Elite" is no where nearly challenging. Again
votesHelpful: this points back to the various mini-games and the DFM.\nIf you get the hang of the DFM (and you will within 10 minutes) you'll be shooting down the hardest Aces in mere minutes (so long as it's not a scripted event). You can take MULTIPLE missle hits on Elite
votesTotal: to which your plane will seemingly regenerate health. You have unlimited bullets (not like they do anything to begin with) and still have over ONE HUNDRED missiles on Elite.\nYou can almost Bounce off the ground on Elite
votesFunny:
something only seen in previous games on the easiest difficulties.

-Fifth. PC edition flaws and other crap
The controls are quite awful to get a handle on. You really must have a controller to "enjoy" this game because Mouse control won't help in the slightest and trying to fly with the bloody Arrow keys is near impossible. Of course
commentsCount: all to be expected from a Console series.\nThere's no real PC settings to get a hold of. Just resolution
column16: AA and some other things. This was quite sad to see
column17: since adding AA also adds significant lag for what looks to be little difference.\n\nNow the game itself looks good. Like DAMN good. They finally made the environments you play in interesting and vibrant. Not the flat Google-Earth imagery of old. The planes explode and tear apart magnificiently. Character models are well done. Overall
column18:
a good job. On the graphics.

Multiplayer is mostly everything above only with REAL PEOPLE.
I enjoyed it
column19: even with DFM. Sadly
column20: I don't buy ACE games for Multiplayer so I'll just leave it at that.\n\nAnother minor annoyance that came with the "Enhanced Edition" was the inclusion of those stupid
column21: stupid IDOLMASTER skins that I hate oh so much from Ace 6. God damn
column22:
we don't need stupid pink anime skins in Ace Combat. Even if a small ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ portion of the fanbase asks for it. Just don't. Please. The Nagase fanservice was bad enough.


-----TL;DR

Overall I give this game a 5/10. It's just Average

reviewText:
The storyline doesn't stand up to the other AC's storylines, but it had the best gameplay out of any of the ACs I've played (4,5,Zero,6)

For the best game experience possible go to settings and set the control scheme from optimum to classic (Gives you more control over your craft.) and play with a controller. (However it DOES work with mouse and keyboard.)

Even though it's a good game, few people play online and those who do frequently abuse poor balancing decisions

Don't be thrown off by the bad reviews, they're most likely people who didn't know they could change the control scheme to classic, or people upset that the gameplay has shyed-away from slow turn fights.

The soundtrack is amazing by the way, look it up. Naval Warfare" is my favorite

Also
date: Angry Joe has an excellent review I would recommend watching if you're on the fence about this game. As well as the game putting you into the action fairly quickly before the steam refunds 2 hour limit is up."

reviewText:
if you are a fan of the Ace Combat series, Assault horizon is a Different kind of beast. so,since now,i warn you. Aproach this one with caution.

well,it feels like ace combat,plays for the most part like ace combat, but it has one mechanic that Kills it,DFM and ASM. those sections,when Scripted are Terrible,and makes the fights with aces,Especially the one with a certain shark nosed Plane Pilot, Unfufilling. At First,they are cool,but repeat them,over,and over,and over again,and you'll see what i mean. and this is agravated if you played other Ace Combat games on the consoles, that really demanded skills from you.

so,it's a Hard game?! Far from it. Easy,even on the Ace Difficulty,but it has it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t moments.
Is a Bad Ace combat game?! by my standards,Yes. Namco has done better with its franchises.
But it's a Bad game?! HELL NO.

The better pros i gotta say is: the cutscenes that are awesomely made, the Aircraft Collor editor that even to this date i revisit, and the Awesome models,beautifull with full interiors made by Project aces.

But the Unforgivable Cons i gotta repeat: The DFM and ASM are not good systems when done Scripted like 60% of the game. some sections are not,but they fell a bit cluncky to control,and i tend to lose control quickly. another Con is that the control on this game is very sensitive,even on the most Non-Sensitive setting,so it doesn't feel like Ace 5,6,or Cross Rumble,and you get to have tighter reflexes to adapt on how the Jets fly on this game. they feel different,but horrible?! no... just,worse. and those aspects i'm glad that namcobandai got right on the next games of the franchise,that can and MUST keep going in the direction it was since Ace Combat 3 (jp)... that by the way i still wait for a remake of that game... but let's not get out of the tangent.

My final Veredict: 7/10.  Is not a Bad game, i can recomend for you who want a Different Experience all togheter.
But if you are a Ace fan,as a said Aproach with caution or Don't go for it.(or at least,wait untill the price drop if you want to experiment with this beast).

reviewText:
Ace Combat: Assault Horizon is probably the best arcade/flight simulator I got on PC. Although it doesn't near good enough as the Playstation 2 titles but still fun to play, the Dogfight Mode is kinda awesome although sometimes I hate it when some enemies are requiring DFM to be destroyed. I don't even mind those Modern Military Shooter-esque plot as long as it's sensible.

Verdict: 8/10

Recommended for those who seeks the fast-paced arcade/flight simulator and not Recommended for those who prefer the old classic AC gameplay.

reviewText:
Freedom! Terrorists! USA Number One!

Not recommended. Mostly because this is not a game. It's a press-space-to-win Murica propaganda video.

First, the storyline. Don't worry, there isn't one. You're firstly thrown into a dogfight with some invaders in SU27s - oh look, Default Enemy #1 - The Russians. Why are they invading? Why are they attacking Miami? Who knows. Second mission - oh look, you're in the desert. But no, this isn't Iraq (yet. I assume that comes later) and you're shooting 'rebels'. This is the point where it turned my stomach. No motivation, no cause, just some guys trying to run away and getting gunned down by the USMC.

No.

At this point the second HUGE problem of the game kicked in and I just couldn't play any more - motion sickness. Sometimes you have control, sometimes you don't. Dogfight mode puts everything RIGHT UP IN YOUR GRILL and you have to fight with the terrible control system to get a lock. It also seems to have some kind of selective auto-aim that throws the camera off as well - so you're basically spending half the time trying to chase an enemy and the other half fighting the camera.

I felt so sick by the end of the second mission, I had to stop.

Whilst I'm talking about the controls, Why can't I fly with the mouse? Why am I using the keyboard? The keyboard isn't a controller. I've never used WSAD as controls to look around.

Basically, this game is garbage. Battlefield 4 has better aerial combat than this. Everything this game is meant to do, it does badly, and blasts its message of American superiority so hard it makes Call of Duty look like a balanced view of world politics. Spend your £2.49 on an American flag and go and stand in your local park yelling xenophobic comments at people instead.

reviewText:
Freedom! Terrorists! USA Number One!

Not recommended. Mostly because this is not a game. It's a press-space-to-win Murica propaganda video.

First, the storyline. Don't worry, there isn't one. You're firstly thrown into a dogfight with some invaders in SU27s - oh look, Default Enemy #1 - The Russians. Why are they invading? Why are they attacking Miami? Who knows. Second mission - oh look, you're in the desert. But no, this isn't Iraq (yet. I assume that comes later) and you're shooting 'rebels'. This is the point where it turned my stomach. No motivation, no cause, just some guys trying to run away and getting gunned down by the USMC.

No.

At this point the second HUGE problem of the game kicked in and I just couldn't play any more - motion sickness. Sometimes you have control, sometimes you don't. Dogfight mode puts everything RIGHT UP IN YOUR GRILL and you have to fight with the terrible control system to get a lock. It also seems to have some kind of selective auto-aim that throws the camera off as well - so you're basically spending half the time trying to chase an enemy and the other half fighting the camera.

I felt so sick by the end of the second mission, I had to stop.

Whilst I'm talking about the controls, Why can't I fly with the mouse? Why am I using the keyboard? The keyboard isn't a controller. I've never used WSAD as controls to look around.

Basically, this game is garbage. Battlefield 4 has better aerial combat than this. Everything this game is meant to do, it does badly, and blasts its message of American superiority so hard it makes Call of Duty look like a balanced view of world politics. Spend your £2.49 on an American flag and go and stand in your local park yelling xenophobic comments at people instead.

Spend your £2.49 on an American flag and go and stand in your local park yelling xenophobic comments at people instead.

reviewText:
As a series-long fan I was initially concerned about the more realistic direction that the franchise seemed to be taking with Assualt Horizon. However, because I enjoy the development team and flying games in general, I gave it a shot. Other than to satiate curiosity, I wish I hadn't given the game my time.

While the flying itself is solid, the introduction of the dogfighting mode added cinematic flair, but also removed me from the action. Additionally, during some of the larger skirmishes, it seemed to open me up to more missile shots than I'd normally expect in an Ace Combat game (even on harder difficulties). The fighter gameplay is acceptable, though not on par with the other entries in the series, and unfortunately new flight additions to the game only detracted from the experience.

The helicopter controls didn't feel quite right, nor did the shooting while on board. I see what the devs were going for, but they didn't succeed in it. Likewise, the AC-130 experience was virtually ripped from Call of Duty: Modern Warfare. Certainly there's only so much one can do with an AC-130, but the experience felt put in to appeal to a broader audience, but at the cost of what Ace Combat has been about for almost 20 years.

Graphically the game is solid, nice effects. The soundtrack was fairly forgettable, standard military game fair. The controls were solid (I used a wired 360 gamepad), so no big complaints there.

Finally, the story wasn't the fantasy/reality blend of previous titles, but more standard military drama with obvious plot twists that one could see from 40,000 ft. As a fan I was not impressed, and frankly other games have told the same story in better ways.

Ultimately, I would not recommend purchasing Assault Horizon unless you need an arcade flying game fix. Previous Ace Combat games were better, there are a great deal of excellent flying games on the PC to play instead of this.

reviewText:
As a longtime fan of the Ace Combat series, I have always enjoyed it's place in the arcade fighter simulator genre. Cool planes, crazy aerial boss battles, canyon/trench run challenges and conflicts in the fictional Ace Combat universe were hallmarks of the series. Unfortunately, Assault Horizon decided to completely throw out many of the core gameplay elements and themes that had made previous Ace Combat games so enjoyable, and decided to pursue a Call-of-Duty approach to gameplay and storyline.

One of the most egregious additions is the Dog-fighting mode, where with the press of 2 buttons, your plane magically maneuevers itself on the tail of the enemy and sticks there with minimal effort. Meant to highlight the action" it just turns dogfighting into a glorified QTE.

One new direction that AC:AH took that had promise
recommended: was the expansion into other types of aircraft
hoursPlayed: including bombers and helicopters. Unfortunately
voteText: these levels seemed less about flying and more about aiming your recticle over targets on a screen (think AC-130). The end result was gimmicky execution of what could have been some very interesting and fun set pieces.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: AC:AH has been a disappoinment. It could not deliver the experience of previous installments and failed to win me over with its new mechanics."

reviewText:
Ace Combat Assault Horizon

I loaded Ace Combat 5 into my PS2 and was blown away. Everything about that game was great. I mean, that game was perfection. I beat it on the hardest difficulty and unlocked all the secrets just because I loved the game so much.

When I got ACAH it was still GFWL. Now it's not anymore but I've already beaten it at this point. Seeing as the campaign was VERY hand holdy and there wasn't much room for amazing dog fights with the DFM. DFM basically rails you onto a line and takes you through a QTE.

The storyline was average. I suppose I shouldn't have expected more. AC5 was corny as well but it was a better corny. ACAH was just convoluted. They dropped the alternate reality in favor of putting it in the real world and they got rid of all the sci-fi elements in favor of... giving the main character a premonition?

Also, by default you are in Casual flight mode, which I didn't realize meant that you couldn't preform rolls. Turn that off as fast as you can. It's just not right for it to even be on.

reviewText:
Free is too expensive.

But in case you need more convincing, let me tell you what's what. Ace Combat is not - and never has been - a flight sim. It's a long-running franchise hailing from Japan, eminently focused on high-speed arcade action. It has always had very, very little at all to do with reality, save the inclusion of detailed plane models based mostly on real-life military fighters and bombers.

As a flight-sim enthusiast, some would consider it a crime for me to admit that I really do enjoy arcade flight games. They're a great fallback for those times when you want to splash some bogies, but you don't have the time or the inclination to go full-real (or even semi-real, honestly).

I've played Ace Combat games for years, since I was a kid, and it was probably Ace Combat among other games that helped foster my later interest in more authentic fare. I started with Ace Combat 2: Electrosphere on the original Playstation, and let me tell you: the title of that game says it all. Ace Combat has a track record of featuring crazy, wonky, way-out-there fantasy elements, up to and including the absurdly massive flying superweapons that are a genuine staple of the franchise.

Ace Combat was never about being serious. It was about flying around a surprisingly well-modeled, realistic-looking plane incongruously stuffed with 200-plus anti-everything missiles, and blowing things up with reckless abandon. This and Armored Core was where it was at back in the day, and it was a glorious time to grow up in.

Now, AC4 tried to shake things up a bit by introducing a relatable" "story" with "characters" and such. And it's fairly poor. Thankfully
date: it doesn't detract from gameplay too much
recommended: as the background chatter is easy to tune out
hoursPlayed: but if examined at length...oh boy. The writing was chunky and oftentimes silly
voteText: and the low-grade-anime-quality voice actors delivering the lines made for a very embarrassing experience.\n\n"Yeah
helpfulPercent: we won! Now let's sing our dramatically overwrought national anthem as the camera pans dramatically around our planes! YEAH!"\n\nBut AC5 didn't improve its horrible dialog and hand-wringingly bad voice acting. In fact
votesHelpful: it made it *worse
votesTotal: * as "story" became an increasing focus. And then AC6? Oh my and dear me. Just go YouTube the intro
votesFunny: or look up "dance with the angels - " actually
commentsCount: no. Don't do that. You'll die of embarrassment. Actually
column16: you should
column17: because the sheer temple-drilling horribleness of that dialogue atrocity is actually important to this review.\n\nFor years
column18: the core gameplay never really changed between sequels. It was all about going from one target to the next
column19: getting a lock-on
column20: and then double-tapping the missile button to launch precisely two missiles
column21: and flying off to the next enemy. It's fun
column22: for a while
column23: but without any real evolution going on in the background
column24: franchise fatigue was inevitable.\n\nSo what did they change? Is this game "Call of Duty with wings
column25: as so many reviews claim? Ha, well, the answer is that they changed everything, while actually changing nothing. Let me explain in brief.\n\nThe innovations" consist of one central new "feature:" Dog-Fight Mode. That's right. "Mode." As in
column26: one of the core aspects of air combat is now a "mode." There's also a differently-named variant for ground attacks
column27: but it's the exact same concept: press a combination of two buttons
column28: and you lock into a more or less on-rails scripted sequence where you keep your target or targets centered while your missiles lock on.\n\nI don't even really mind the system in theory. Really
column29: they HAD to do something to change things up
column30: because even as a long-time AC fan
column31: I was getting bored of the one-button double-tap missile fest the game had stubbornly been for years.  What they were trying to achieve with DFM was to add some depth to air battles
column32: make them more dependent on timing and reading movements. It actually plays much better in practice than it sounds going by my description of it. But here's the problem: occasionally
column33: the game uses DFM as an excuse to pretty much put you through an on-rails theme-park ride that's scripted to the end. Don't balk too much - after all
column34: Grand Theft Auto has been doing the exact same thing for years with every single one of its "dramatic car chases
column35:
and it's a million seller. But let's be honest - it still sucks.

DFM is actually okay on its own. It's got flaws, but the core idea is sound. It takes all the concepts of energy and g-forces and simplifies the crap out of them so as not to burden the core arcade experience with excessive realism, giving the occasional dog-fight a fraction of the intensity and strategy of the real thing. The enemy suddenly peels left, so you have to slow and follow to keep from losing him. He dives and burns, so you have to throttle up to keep pace. A lot of scripting is required, sure, and all of these maneuvers do constitute a sort of timing mini-game in all honesty, but still, the nature of the game's AI would ordinarily prevent exciting dog-fights from actually taking place to begin with. So in that regard, it's nice to have a sort-of-dog-fight experience every once in a while.

The problem is when DFM triggers a heavily-scripted setpiece, as mentioned above. It tends to happen at least twice per mission, and you have little to no actual control over the events. Your subject plane becomes temporarily immune to all damage until a sufficiently exciting number of explosions occur within your relative field of view, and the setpiece is over.

It's fun the first time, sure, but if you eat a missile (or two, or three) and die, and one of those setpieces occurs after your last checkpoint, be prepared for your next DFM attempt to trigger the exact same pseudo-cutscene again. It will do so the next time you die, too. And the next time.

Thankfully, most enemies can be defeated the old-school double-tap way, but you're still avoiding an entire facet of the gameplay. It sucks because these scripted moments, when they do occur, detract from the good the devs achieved, and all but ruin the feature completely. Regular DFM battles are just fine.

The ground attacks, though, are boiled crap. They force you on a linear path, often against ALL COMMON SENSE, and it becomes a game of struggling with the lock toggle to send your missiles to the right target. It's just plain horrible, and unlike DFM, it's straight-up forced on you. Do it, or mail your fission, 'cause it's game over.

The devs know all about the importance of cushioning a bad landing. In case their grand gameplay experiment failed, they needed a scapegoat to blame for the negative reviews. And so: thematic shift! They hired a half-decent American writer to pen an actually coherent script, applied some color-grading to the post, and for the first time placed the game's events in the real world. So of course the new direction of the plot" was the game's real failing. Oh

reviewText:
A crushing disappointment and a total let down.

This game doesn't even let you barrel roll nor does it let you fly upside down, you have very little control over the aircraft which, if you're anything like me, completely ruins the game as it doesn't let you have the play/flying style that you need. You can move side-to-side or up and down, diagnal movement happens but it is clunky and forced.

If you're looking for an Ace Combat game that, you know, let's you fly a plane, then this is not it.

If you're looking for a fight simulator that holds your hand and confides you to its own will, then this is perfect.

I rate it: unbelievebly disappointing/10

reviewText:
Free is too expensive.

But in case you need more convincing, let me tell you what's what. Ace Combat is not - and never has been - a flight sim. It's a long-running franchise hailing from Japan, eminently focused on high-speed arcade action. It has always had very, very little at all to do with reality, save the inclusion of detailed plane models based mostly on real-life military fighters and bombers.

As a flight-sim enthusiast, some would consider it a crime for me to admit that I really do enjoy arcade flight games. They're a great fallback for those times when you want to splash some bogies, but you don't have the time or the inclination to go full-real (or even semi-real, honestly).

I've played Ace Combat games for years, since I was a kid, and it was probably Ace Combat among other games that helped foster my later interest in more authentic fare. I started with Ace Combat 2: Electrosphere on the original Playstation, and let me tell you: the title of that game says it all. Ace Combat has a track record of featuring crazy, wonky, way-out-there fantasy elements, up to and including the absurdly massive flying superweapons that are a genuine staple of the franchise.

Ace Combat was never about being serious. It was about flying around a surprisingly well-modeled, realistic-looking plane incongruously stuffed with 200-plus anti-everything missiles, and blowing things up with reckless abandon. This and Armored Core was where it was at back in the day, and it was a glorious time to grow up in.

Now, AC4 tried to shake things up a bit by introducing a relatable" "story" with "characters" and such. And it's fairly poor. Thankfully
date: it doesn't detract from gameplay too much
recommended: as the background chatter is easy to tune out
hoursPlayed: but if examined at length...oh boy. The writing was chunky and oftentimes silly
voteText: and the low-grade-anime-quality voice actors delivering the lines made for a very embarrassing experience.\n\n"Yeah
helpfulPercent: we won! Now let's sing our dramatically overwrought national anthem as the camera pans dramatically around our planes! YEAH!"\n\nBut AC5 didn't improve its horrible dialog and hand-wringingly bad voice acting. In fact
votesHelpful: it made it *worse
votesTotal: * as "story" became an increasing focus. And then AC6? Oh my and dear me. Just go YouTube the intro
votesFunny: or look up "dance with the angels - " actually
commentsCount: no. Don't do that. You'll die of embarrassment. Actually
column16: you should
column17: because the sheer temple-drilling horribleness of that dialogue atrocity is actually important to this review.\n\nFor years
column18: the core gameplay never really changed between sequels. It was all about going from one target to the next
column19: getting a lock-on
column20: and then double-tapping the missile button to launch precisely two missiles
column21: and flying off to the next enemy. It's fun
column22: for a while
column23: but without any real evolution going on in the background
column24: franchise fatigue was inevitable.\n\nSo what did they change? Is this game "Call of Duty with wings
column25: as so many reviews claim? Ha, well, the answer is that they changed everything, while actually changing nothing. Let me explain in brief.\n\nThe innovations" consist of one central new "feature:" Dog-Fight Mode. That's right. "Mode." As in
column26: one of the core aspects of air combat is now a "mode." There's also a differently-named variant for ground attacks
column27: but it's the exact same concept: press a combination of two buttons
column28: and you lock into a more or less on-rails scripted sequence where you keep your target or targets centered while your missiles lock on.\n\nI don't even really mind the system in theory. Really
column29: they HAD to do something to change things up
column30: because even as a long-time AC fan
column31: I was getting bored of the one-button double-tap missile fest the game had stubbornly been for years.  What they were trying to achieve with DFM was to add some depth to air battles
column32: make them more dependent on timing and reading movements. It actually plays much better in practice than it sounds going by my description of it. But here's the problem: occasionally
column33: the game uses DFM as an excuse to pretty much put you through an on-rails theme-park ride that's scripted to the end. Don't balk too much - after all
column34: Grand Theft Auto has been doing the exact same thing for years with every single one of its "dramatic car chases
column35:
and it's a million seller. But let's be honest - it still sucks.

DFM is actually okay on its own. It's got flaws, but the core idea is sound. It takes all the concepts of energy and g-forces and simplifies the crap out of them so as not to burden the core arcade experience with excessive realism, giving the occasional dog-fight a fraction of the intensity and strategy of the real thing. The enemy suddenly peels left, so you have to slow and follow to keep from losing him. He dives and burns, so you have to throttle up to keep pace. A lot of scripting is required, sure, and all of these maneuvers do constitute a sort of timing mini-game in all honesty, but still, the nature of the game's AI would ordinarily prevent exciting dog-fights from actually taking place to begin with. So in that regard, it's nice to have a sort-of-dog-fight experience every once in a while.

The problem is when DFM triggers a heavily-scripted setpiece, as mentioned above. It tends to happen at least twice per mission, and you have little to no actual control over the events. Your subject plane becomes temporarily immune to all damage until a sufficiently exciting number of explosions occur within your relative field of view, and the setpiece is over.

It's fun the first time, sure, but if you eat a missile (or two, or three) and die, and one of those setpieces occurs after your last checkpoint, be prepared for your next DFM attempt to trigger the exact same pseudo-cutscene again. It will do so the next time you die, too. And the next time.

Thankfully, most enemies can be defeated the old-school double-tap way, but you're still avoiding an entire facet of the gameplay. It sucks because these scripted moments, when they do occur, detract from the good the devs achieved, and all but ruin the feature completely. Regular DFM battles are just fine.

The ground attacks, though, are boiled crap. They force you on a linear path, often against ALL COMMON SENSE, and it becomes a game of struggling with the lock toggle to send your missiles to the right target. It's just plain horrible, and unlike DFM, it's straight-up forced on you. Do it, or mail your fission, 'cause it's game over.

The devs know all about the importance of cushioning a bad landing. In case their grand gameplay experiment failed, they needed a scapegoat to blame for the negative reviews. And so: thematic shift! They hired a half-decent American writer to pen an actually coherent script, applied some color-grading to the post, and for the first time placed the game's events in the real world. So of course the new direction of the plot" was the game's real failing. Oh

reviewText:
Pros

Cons

Conclusion
- Yet I still recommend this game. Dogfighting in pink F-22 is always refreshing.

reviewText: I downloaded this game in a fit of anticipation, but have never felt such crushing disappointment. I hadn't seen a new Ace Wombat game in years, and never dreamed that my childhood favourite would ever hit the PC. Back in the early 90s,  gaming was all about the three big console mascots: Super Mario, Sonic the Hedgehog and the unforgettable Ace Wombat. While Ace never quite had the broad mainstream appeal of Nintendo and Sega's icons, the adventures of the cheeky, baseball-cap wearing marsupial filled my childhood with near-limitless joy.\n\n1993's original The Adventures of Ace Wombat redefined 16-bit platforming with its streetwise style, punishing bosses and catchy gangsta rap soundtrack. The 1995 sequel, Ace Wombat 2: Marsupial Madness, was much of the same, ableit with a superior level of polish and new multiplayer modes featuring Danny the Disco Dingo (I'm sure we all remember his awesome catchphrase: Can you dig it?"). 1997 brought the first shaky 3D effort: Ace Wombat vs. the Lizard of Oz. Unfairly maligned at the time for its awkward camera controls and risque tone
date: Ace 3D pioneered gameplay and storytelling techniques that wouldn't be adopted by the mainstream until the PS2 era.\n\nSadly
recommended: following the lackluster commercial performance of Ace 3D
hoursPlayed: the franchise was put on hiatus for almost a decade
voteText: and only the most ardent fans held out hope for a return. However
helpfulPercent: in 2006 our prayers were finally answered with the phenomenal 4Ce Womb4t: The 4th Wall. Informed by lead designer Trip Hazard's battles with substance abuse in those dark days
votesHelpful: The 4th Wall was a  surreal
votesTotal: dreamlike trip into the psyche of one of gaming's iconic figures. Blending the game space with reality and destroying the lines between player and avatar
votesFunny: it takes inspiration from sources as diverse as the games of Hideo Kojima
commentsCount: the artwork of MC Escher and the literature of Jorge Luis Borges. Unfortunately
column16: the experimental nature of the game didn't translate into solid sales
column17: and the studio was shuttered soon after. We all thought the story would end there.\n\nNow
column18: imagine my astonishment when I see Ace Wombat: Assault Horizon pop up on Steam. I furiously charged through the payment and download screens
column19: palms sweating with anticipation. As the download ebbed and flowed I found my heart beginning to race. Finally - a new Ace Wombat game
column20: out of the blue after so many years of silence.\n\nSadly
column21: it wasn't to be. They had lied. Exploiting my cherished memories of youth
column22: they'd cruelly duped me into buying yet another cookie-cutter military shooter
column23: albeit with the standard ground combat supplanted by aircraft. Where was my beloved Ace Wombat
column24: whizzing across the screen on his rollerblades? Where was the Acemobile? Where the hell was Danny the Disco Dingo???\n\nNamco. Bandai. A plague on both your houses!"

reviewText:
Just by the name alone, if you ask any of the long time fans, they'll tell you what they think at the drop of a hat.
Having played through the campaign fully, I can see just why this game was made. The article I read prior to playing the game comparing it to a certain hyper-popular first-person shooter cemented my opinion in stone already. One part of me wants to like this game, but the other part screams at it in disgust.

Ace Combat Assault horizon is a frank departure from the series established bizzaro earth in which it takes place in the more familiar setting of our world. It seeks to establish a cast of loveable characters from the outset with plenty of dialogue inbetween missions.
While the game certainly stands on its own as a certifyable Ace combat game, it definitely has the feel most fans of the series have come to expect, but has a flawed core that sours the experience.

From the core, it tends to lean to hard on its own gimmicks to draw in new players, and it shows in the gameplay, the addition of Dog-fight Mode is a sort of,On Rails" mode to help new players take on enemies.

its an easier to control help-to-kill method

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY if youre a fan of the original Ace Combat series on PS2. An Ace Combat game that's completely on the rails. The only effective way to shoot down aircraft is through a dogfight mode which flies the aircraft for you, the movement is so erratic in this mode that it just gets annoying over time to try and focus the cursor over the enemy jet while it's doing 10g moves. Most of these dogfight sequences are heavily scripted with the enemy jet not blowing up until you pass through scenic explosions and carnage that wouldn't have happened otherwise and that's what bugs me the most. Sometimes planes can take 2 missiles and explode which is usually the fastest some standard jet planes can go down, but sometimes planes can also take up to 4-6 missile hits and a barrage of guns only to explode after we see some stylized collateral damage.

The story is also uninspiring when compared to past Ace Combat games. Anything interesting in the plot could've been seen a mile away with as the game tries to hold your hand through its already weak plot.

The game tries to make up for its lackluster gameplay by expanding on what you can do in the game: bombing and helicopter assaults. Helicopter missions are a bit weak while the bombing ones are actually interesting althought there is only a total of 1 bombing mission in the game.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this game if you're a fan of the series or want to avoid an on the rails game.

reviewText:
Pros
- You can fly planes with Project IM@S skin and rub Yayoi chan's awesomeness in the face of evil Russians
- Realistic and well polished aircraft designs compare to other aircraft shooting games.
- The game system is quite actiony and unique compare to other aircraft shooting games.
- Cool finishing motions.
- Your 12 years old child will totally love it.

Cons
- Ultimately ♥♥♥♥ story and its also quite short.
- Repetitive and stupid game system. It just keep spams Close Range Assult system.
- You buy this game to fly fighter planes, but there are many missions which you have to become a gunner of AC130 gunship or control helicopters. Those missions are just full of stupidity. Its a bad influence from CoD.
- So much unnecessary explosions that Michael Bay would totally fap to this crap.
- Stupid in-game cut scenes that decreases your IQ.

Conclusion
- Yet I still recommend this game. Dogfighting in pink F-22 is always refreshing.

reviewText:
It's ♥♥♥♥.

Do not buy this game, even if it's deeply discounted. Pretty much everything about is an absolute cluster♥♥♥♥. The 'innovative' gameplay features seem like they were specifically designed to disempower the player; you'll be groaning every time an enemy flight lead shows up because you'll know you have to engage in the godawful dogfight mode, flying around in a nauseating chase sequence while your target implausibly and frustratingly soaks up missile after missile. And that's far from the only problem with the game. Especially horrible is the way the game frequently decides to ♥♥♥♥ with you by messing with the camera.

Oddly the tacked on Call of Duty-ish elements, namely the helicopter doorgunner and AC-130 fire support missions were the most fun I got out of the game (the attack helicopter ones however are pretty awful). Although I have to say the doorgunner mission at the start of the game is extremely disturbing; it's essentially a war crimes simulation. No, the throwaway line about it being a UN santioned operation and the area being a 'free-fire zone' doesn't excuse it. Anyone who has ever read in-depth about about the Vietnam War knows what utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t a free-fire designation is.

On the plus side there's some very nice music (a franchise staple) and the graphics engine is genuinely impressive and versatile, delivering good up-close visuals of humans and other on-the-ground elements in addition to the usual aircraft fare. Which only makes it more of a shame that they decided to waste the effort and budget on this crappy real world Tom Clancy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t narrative, instead of giving us what everyone actually wants, which is a true Strangereal Ace Combat 7.

The narrative deserves special attention because of how downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and Russophobic it is. I understand why Russia keeps showing up over and over again as villains in these types of stories; it's the only vaguely credible threat to the American Empire left on the planet, aside from China which is too important a trade partner to risk villifying. But generally there's at least an attempt at nuance. Here's the entire message of Assault Horizon: Russians are backstabbing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, all of them. Except the token 'good' Russian, who is a nice subservient pet to our glorious American protaganists. No, just kidding, he's also a backstabbing traitorous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, he was only pretending to be good. That's literally it. The villains entire motivation is that American bombing accidentally killed his waifu in Bosnia. I'm not even kidding or oversimplifying, that is literally it.

Compare this to something like Call of Duty 4 (let's try and forget the sequels...) which still had shades of Russophobia but at least bothered to divide them into 'good' and 'bad' Russians via a civil war plotline. In that game the chief antagonist Imran Zakhaev actually had a fairly credible motivation, though it wasn't given much attention. The line he gives in the games intro about Russian leaders prostituting their populations to the West and destroying their cultures and economies is 100% factual. The historical reality is that in the immediate aftermath of the collapse of the Soviet Union Russia was set to make the transition to a Scandanavian-style Social Democracy, because, whatever Americans may think, most Russians genuinely liked many aspects of the USSR, like socialized medicine and education. At which point the West, spearheaded by financial institutions like Goldman Sachs, stepped in and said 'no, what you really want is rampant privitization'. Yeltsin said 'okay', and the country was utterly exploited. A new aristrocracy of oligarchs rose to power, controlling most of the wealth and resources, and around 10 million people prematurely died, many simply drinking themselves to death in despair. Given that reality, the idea of a guy wanting to nuke the ♥♥♥♥ out of America isn't hard to believe.

Similarly Khaled Al-Asad and his generic Middle-Eastern 'separatists' have genuine grievences, though they're inevitably portrayed as genocidal monsters. Especially in light of the real-world Arab Spring where it became painfully obvious just how despised by their populations the US-backed dictatorships of the region were. Oh but don't worry, that annoying 'democracy' thing didn't last long in Egypt at any rate, and the US is backing a new military dictatorship.

Compare both those motivations to 'bombs killed my girlfriend'. Yeah...

tl;dr go play Vector Thrust, and/or resume grinding through sorties in Ace Combat Infinity. This game is ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
This game was recently patched to remove the GFWL which is good.  However the game is still contains gamebreaking bugs.  At first when I got this I couldnt even start the game using a controller the menu would just infinitely scroll.  While I may expect that using a third party controller this is a standard everyday no frills wireless 360 controller.  Before the patch I couldnt start the game.  With the patch I can start the game and the jet parts with fights work well.  Anything with a helicopter it seems are broken and the triggers dont work for some reason.  I dont know if it will be patched now its been years for them to make the menu work so I could launch the game and maybe in a few years the helicopter part will work, who knows.

The jet flying for aerial combat is pretty strange, enemy planes tend to fly in circles right around you or right behind you for some reason.  There is an odd mechanic where if a plane is behind you, you can QTE by pressing LB + RB and you flip behind the plane somehow and you blow them up.  This is odd because in the game this maneuver cant be performed as in you cant do a flip in your plane.  So yea its real basic and I guess half the game works if its split between jet fights and helicopter fights since the helicopter fights dont work with a controller.  There is also no horizon control meaning if you turn right you turn right, and there is no way to keep the plane level or adjust this making this just a terrible flying game in general since even the basic ability of being able to play is it messed up so badly.

The game uses a VATS shooting thing like from fallout but in this game its called DFM for DogFight Mode.  Its a zoomed in battle making it like an FPS in the air.  A strange choice for an aerial combat game and doesnt really feel like it belongs and isnt very fun.  The concept should be fly a plane and blow up stuff, not change to FPS mode to do it, it just doesnt make any sense.

Still broken, but the jets controls work now, so its half a game.
Rating:  0/10  Value:  $0.00

reviewText:
Ace Combat Assault Horizon - Enhanced Edition is the Seventh Ace Combat game in the series, released on the PS3 and Xbox 360 in 2011 and on Steam for the PC in 2013. This was my first foray into playing the Ace Combat games on the PC, so I was surprised by the keyboard controls without the need for the mouse. This Ace Combat features CRA, Close-Range Assault, in-game known as Dogfighting Mode. This is different, as once it is engaged you are zoned in on a target and must navigate in tandum with the enemy pilot to lock missles, or just blast it with guns. Visually, I like the way Ace Combat Assault Horizon looks, especially in Dogfighting mode. This game would definitely be next-level with a flight stick and controls, as opposed to a keyboard, but is still fun. I recommend playing on harder settings as the easier settings do not present much of a challenge.

The game allows you to control a stealth bomber, AC-130, fighter jet and a helicopter throughout campaign play. You can also play in Multiplayer mode, either through coop missions or in a free for all deathmatch. In all it was a fun game to play, as well as exciting. I think if you like games where you have to pilot aircraft and enjoy a fast-paced gameplay, this is going to be up your alley.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.
Let's see...how to begin this.  I love the Ace Combat series.  So much that I have some sort of stockholm syndrome and ignore the normal cheesy 'writers do no research on war' storylines.
First, unless this game is ~$5, DO NOT BUY IT. Period.  Your steam code will not activate GFWL.  That means no multiplayer.   Half the game gone like that.  There is no solution.  Steam will direct you to GFWL and GFWL will direct you to Steam, any further comments will be auto-ignored. Seriously, read the discussion boards.
The highlight of this game was Written by americans who professionally write tom clancy style novels".  Not only does this not fix the writing problem previously stated
date: but it's more painful because its set in the real world.  The writers obviously did not google "NATO relations with Russia".  Real world makes it worse if you know anything about history.  Let's move on to the game.  Plenty to talk about DogFightMode.  You can see the good idea behind it
recommended: except that it forces you to use it.  It forces you because half the enemies are immune to damage unless you DFM them.   Camera angles are jacked up.  The camera does not stick behind you like all 7 previous games and when doing maneuvers will face the ground making sure you have no idea where you are guiding yourself exactly.\nSpeaking of controls
hoursPlayed: they put a flight game on the PC and gave it no flightstick support.  The xbox AC games have support....and a special flightstick made for it.  WTF.  BIGGEST PROBLEM WITH THE GAME : PACING.  Cutscenes are fine and help develop stories
voteText: but do I need to be forced to walk through hallways in buildings for 5 minutes only allowed to turn my head and looks a people with no interaction?  It does not help except to give me time to get a beer from the fridge.  In game too
helpfulPercent: many missions including the helo/gunner missions just drag on...sometimes for 40 minutes.  There is no skill in these modes
votesHelpful: but it just wont stop.  I want to pass it to get to the next jetfighter mission
votesTotal: so I just rubber band the trigger (hint: you cant die and you have infinite ammo).  The helo mission don't even fit into the story flow and little reason is given.  It is direct jealousy of the Call Of Battlefield franchises. Just like how the R6 games failed starting with R6V2.  The last part I will comment about is the skill.  There is no thrill anymore because missiles are near infinite
votesFunny: life of you and the enemies regenerate fairly quickly

reviewText:
I am just going to go ahead and say it: This game is pure sex.
By that I mean that most of the combat invovles pressing the right button at the right time and not making any sudden moves. As shallow as this is, it is intense. It is full of quick-time events and cinematics of destroying targets with insane amounts of fire power. One can also have fun customizing the paint job and load out of your favorite aircraft and flying your favorite mission.
All that said, this is not a game for simulator enthusiists. The control is unrealistic and if you can't **** yourself that there is a chance that getting hit with a salvo of missles could kill you, then you will likely get bored. If you're not into flying jets or giant explosions, this game is not for you.
Also, I personally love the power metal-esque sound track.

reviewText:
I didn't expect much from this game but it still managed to disappoint me utterly. I don't even know where to start.
The gameplay is horrible. You basically have 3 ways of destroying the opponent and none of them is fulfilling in the long run. You either press B (on an XBOX controller) to shoot a rocket when the square mark on your opponent turns red and hope it hits. It usually doesn't so then you enter the dogfight mode. This means pressing RB+LB which puts you just right behind your opponent and then you again have to wait for a circle mark to become red and press B to fire missiles. Sometimes when you're in the dogfight mode a script activates and you can see a cam shot of your opponent exploding, which gets boring really fast. The last way to kill an opponent is to do a turn around on him when he tries to rocket you from behind. In that instance you wait for two arrows to cover each other and- guess what- press RB+LB to appear behind the enemy in the dogfight mode again. The whole game is basically a big, repetetive, boring QTE event.
Flying itself is really disappointing. It feels nothing like a plane and every plane model flies exactly the same, despite different stats. The controls are unprecise. Also, I have to mention the camera work- it's just atrocious. The FOV is way too low which makes you see nothing apart from your own machine and after some time spent in the dogfight mode I started feeling dizzy.
You can also fly helicopters- don't get too pumped, though. It comes down to pressing LT when your crosshair is set on a land target and then pressing RT to shoot it- the end. It also induces the most camera problems- cockpit view is the only way to play (it's an opposite story with planes- the cockpit view is utterly useless).
The story is forgettable (blah blah Russians blah blah betrayal blah blah Murica).
Initially I wanted to praise the soundtrack but it becomes repetetive fairly quickly, especially that it plays one chosen track during each mission and hearing it over and over again during missions that can last over 30 minutes makes you sick pretty fast. I'd also like to mention this game features the worst French accent in the history of gaming but it's not a big deal- the voice acting is decent overall.
I'm also under impression that the game tries to artificially prolong your gametime, usually by excessive time pressure, at least in higher levels of difficulty.
Unfortunately, I didn't really enjoy this game for more than initial 30 minutes- and I've raged through my playtime all the way. It's cheap but I wouldn't recommend buying it. Heck, I wouldn't even recommend playing it for free.
If you're looking for a pleasant, semi-challenging game featuring planes (including jets) try War Thunder. It's free and it doesn't try to be something it shouldn't be.

reviewText:
Hello! This is going to be coming from someone whos played Ace Combat X and X2 on the PSP and has finished playing the full campaign in Assauly Horizon.

I'll start by saying the positive and thats that the games got gorgeos graphics. The planes look amazing the the terrain is quite beautiful too. Most of the maps are really well thought out and the artworks on some of the planes are just ridiculous! You get to kill enemies in a pink plane! Things can't get better than that.

Unfortunately, thats where all of the noticable positives end for me. I really dislike the games new dogfight mode. It takes away the skill previously required from the Ace Combat series and in addition to that, it gets boring really quickly. Due to its ease and quickness for taking down enemies, most past players of the franchise may find themselves unwillingly using it to quickly make work of the more than necessary enemies thrown at you. I really dislike the alternate helicopter and gunner missions which take away from the jet fighting albeit the bomber missions are refreshing.

Lastly, I'm really dissapointed with the storyline. It does not make you feel like that Ace from the Gryphon Squadron like the other titles did and it does not live upto, atleast what I believe a true Ace Combat story line. No giant ships, no ridiculos missions, in trying to make it real with real life environments and maps, they took away the awesomeness of being able to take down flying fortresses which was jaw droppingly thrilling.

I understand that this was an experiment, hence did not have a number associated for it, but for a first release, I wish they did not experiment with us. I really do hope they make one with the chemistry the Ace Combat series is known for for the next release :)

reviewText: As a long time fan of the Ace Combat series I would like to say a few things about Ace Combat Assault Horizon a very fun game, great for anyone who is into jets and aircrafts in general, fast paced action and great soundtracks. The series has always had some of the best soundtracks around and Assault horizon delivers again. The graphics are a step ahead of any previous entry into the series, everything is nice to look at esspecialy the jets, there is an ingame viewer just for looking at jets which is great. The story is okay but nothing particularily memorable, same with the characters but the missions are extremely fun to play (multiple times). Now on to the gameplay which has always been great but there a few features added to Assault Horizon, one being DFM which is Dog Fight Mode which basically allowd you to engage your enemy in a closer proximity and puts you right in the action and allows you to pull off some pretty awesome maneuvers BUT these maneuvers are very dumbed down from previous games (before you would have to learn and execute these maneuvers on your own) now you press a couple buttons and its done for you so alot less skill is involved which is a letdown to me. Now this is a port from the console verions of the game and its pretty much a barebones port no extra graphical features just resolution, vsync and AA options which is a big minus to me, but it also includes all the DLC from the console verions which is a plus. All and all though Ace Combat Assault Horizon is a very fun game to play with a few minor flaws in the gameplay which are my own personal taste I'd have to give this a 7.8/10. If you like this game I would recommend picking up a PS2 and playing Ace Combat 4 or 5 which are probaly the best in the series.

reviewText:
Simulator?  No.  The lock-on for missiles is almost inside gun range.  Real world missiles are fired at ranges measured in miles.

There is no standing off, no tactical battles of maintaining distance while reaching your target.  It is all just spinning, twisting, dog-fighting spam with only the most casual regard for physics (hitting the ground kills you - end of physics lesson today).

reviewText:
First of all, if you are an veteran in Ace Combat, forget everything you know about this game before judging. This game, like the developers said, is a test for new systems such as the DFM. Although we have seen that DFM did not work as great as they expected, it was a good try to add more content into the Ace Combat series.

For the ones that just picked this game up and know nothing about Ace Combat, it is important to note that this game itself is quite satisfying. The DFM may be boring and repetitive in the single player, but it is the most thrilling part in the multiplayer. However, there aren't many players in the multiplayer, so try to stick to capital domination and deathmatch or bring a friend to join you in the air.

Overall, AC:AH is a great game in itself. Although it does not fit to the traditional Ace Combat series, it is important to note that this game was a testbed for new ideas, and it has served its purpose well.

reviewText:
Before I say anything else, I should point out that anyone who claims that they can't invert their plane or do a roll in ACAH didn't have the sense to even look at the options menu. Seriously. This option between control styles has been a thing since the PS2 Ace Combat games, and even if it wasn't, why would you not check the options menu?

Moving on...

I actually really like ACAH, but with two major complaints.

What are those complaints?
1. Helicopter missions literally give me a headache. I almost didn't buy the game during the last free weekend because of this.
2. The infamous DFM is required to take down certain enemy aces, and there's no shortage of these aces.

A minor complaint I have is that in the cockpit view, the HUD isn't integrated into the cockpit. I'd be fine with stunting my abilities a bit (as an optional thing of course) to have a slightly more immersive cockpit.

Those two msjor points certainly do damage the game, but it's still an arcade flight game that I find myself coming back to more often than others. It's just a lot of dumb fun. DFM is actually a nice mechanic when it's not shoved down your throat, and being able to get right up into the tail of an opposing fighter as it explodes makes for an interesting change than just seeing a  tiny puff of smoke a kilometer or two away.

DFM for the most part is a system about managing your speed to be able to keep on the tail of an opposing fighter while being able to easily lock onto it and/or shoot it down with machine guns. If you get in too close then an enemy can pull off a counter maneuver to get behind you or simply make a hard brake into a direction you're not expecting to escape your sights, but if you're farther away, your acceptable lock-on circle gets smaller, and obviously it's harder to hit with machine guns. It's not quite as on-rails" as some people would have you believe
date: but it certainly does assist you quite a bit in maneuvering.\n\nAn interesting note relatinmg to DFM is that I find myself actually having to use DFM to perform as well as in other titles. For whatever reason
recommended: pinning an enemy with machine guns seems much harder in ACAH than other arcade flight games I've played. I'm not sure if it's the speed of the game
hoursPlayed: the AI
voteText: or the control sensitivity
helpfulPercent: but there it is. That said
votesHelpful: dropping behind an enemy and firing a couple of missiles works just as well as ever... unless it's an enemy ace. Then it doesn't do anything helpful at all.\n\nAs much as I like DFM
votesTotal: the game would most certainly be better if it didn't shove it down your throat (I know I made this point already
votesFunny: but it needs to be said again). It takes you on scripted sequences through exploding set pieces

reviewText:
Simulator?  No.  The lock-on for missiles is almost inside gun range.  Real world missiles are fired at ranges measured in miles.

There is no standing off, no tactical battles of maintaining distance while reaching your target.  It is all just spinning, twisting, dog-fighting spam with only the most casual regard for physics (hitting the ground kills you - end of physics lesson today).

reviewText:

reviewText: Pure arcade, not really good for you if you are used to play simulators. People often told me that Ace Combat is better than Tom Clancy's HAWX; now I can see that it is not exactly true. Viewing a fighter cockpit from the inside is not enough to make people's feelings authentic or at least close to such. The unability to control your aircraft completely is especially annoying: it simply doesn't let you move as you want to, and it automatically returns to horizontal flight if you stop pressing the movement keys. As a result, you feel clumsy against those super agile enemies, who move so swiftly and easily as if they were flying dishes of some remote sci-tech alien civilization.\nAt the same time, the game is rather spectacular, it is intense, and it offers some lengthy and difficult missions. Graphics is good, storyline is... engaging. An interesting alternative to HAWX. A combination of the two would have made a perfect game.

reviewText: I bought this over the summer during the sale, and I finally got around to playing it now.  Not very impressed.\n\nThe air to air stuff is OK at first, but it very quickly becomes tedious.  Playing with Original controls on Normal difficulty, with a 360 controller, the planes fly well enough and controls are responsive and intuitive.  The targeting system is just OK, a lot of times it's difficult to understand where your target has gone but that's more a matter of getting used to the camera.  The problem with air to air is that it doesn't feel in any way realistic; everyone flips around and the only way to really dogfight is to get close enough to the target to enter the on-rails dogfight mode". reviewText:
A subpar entry in a series of great games.

A few things you need to understand before buying/trying this game:
Ace Combat is not a flight sim
Ace Combat is not meant to be realistic
Ace Combat is primarily a console game

First off, the only graphics option is resolution, and that maxes out a 1440p. Even so, the game looks fairly nice, aside from the annoying static cockpit reflection in cockpit view. The story is a wannabe Tom Clancy USA vs. Russia, which is particularly annoying considering the previous games were set in a very interesting alternate universe with fake countries that are allusions to real life counterparts. Sure, the prewvious stories were corny, but you could get really into them. The story in Assault Horizon is both difficult to get into and corny.
Another issue in this entry is limited plane selection according to the mission. The game has a fairly large selection of planes, but it's wasted potential since you can only use a few each mission.
The music is composed by the same guy who was doing it since 04/5, so it is superb as usual. However, in this entry, the music is different from others in regards to their style.

My biggest issue with this game is that they wanted to attract new fans by making the game Call of Duty style with more emphasis on on-the-rails action than the freeforming fun of previous games.

I recommend all the other games in the series before this one, but Assault Horizon is still a decent arcade air combat game.
However, as an Ace Combat game, Assault Horizon fails in many aspects.
I recommend every previous entry other than this one.
Also, make sure you have a joystick/controller, as it is near unplayable otherwise, especially online.

reviewText: If this is the first game of the Ace Combat franchise you've played, then my review might not be as relevant as it is for veterans.  You have been warned.  And if you're wondering why it says I have 0 hours in the game, it's because I put it down almost immediately.\nThis game feels like a travesty to me, being someone who has been an AC veteran for almost 10 years.  I absolutely adore Ace Combat.  The graphics, story, controls, and gameplay mechanics have always been great.  This game comes along and throws multiple things out the window.  Graphically, it's not bad.  The visual options are extremely limited (basically, all you get to customiz is AA and screen resolution, so you're screwed over if you have a lower-end PC) and some ground textures are a bit shoddy, but the planes all look excellent.  The visuals of shooting down other aircraft are awesome: the explosions are vibrant and detailed, and watching your enemy's plane fall to pieces while spewing unburned fuel everywhere is a sight that doesn't get old.  Do you know what does get old, though?  The on-rails segments.  Dogfight mode?"  Seriously?  In Ace Combat's past
date: you actually needed skill and reflexes to outmaneuver and take down a Yellow or a UAV.  Now
recommended: all you have to do is get close
hoursPlayed: press a button
voteText: and keep your targeting reticule in the general direction of the bogey while you fly along a scripted path and fill him with missiles (side note: sometimes
helpfulPercent: enemies in DFM can take a ridiculous number of hits to kill).  This completely killed the game for me
votesHelpful: especially since it's required for some enemies.  This isn't even bringing up the minigun turret and AC-130 gunner levels.  Another cool thing that Ace Combat had was its place along the realistic-arcadey spectrum.  Almost all of the planes are fully licensed models that exist in the real world
votesTotal: but there's always at least one science fiction superweapon
votesFunny: supervehicle
commentsCount: super-something that you get to fight.  Physics and maneuvers are mostly authentic
column16: but your aircraft can hold 100 missiles and the games' final levels include flying through tight corridors.  This game throws all of the cool science fiction aspects away by going with a "realistic" story set in the real world.  Middle eastern terrorists
column17: Russians
column18: and nuclear weapons are all old hat.  I would rather shoot down the Arkbird any day.  The controls are good if you're using a gamepad.  Playing with a keyboard is either outright terrible or has a fairly high learning curve.  I also hear of poor joystick support
column19: but I don't own one so I can't say anything about it.\nI wanted to like this game.  I really
column20: really did.  But I can't enjoy a game that hijacks one of my favorite franchises and flies it straight into the land of COD and BF campaigns.  That's really what this game feels like to me: it's like Namco tried to shove Ace Combat into the skies above the world of extremely scripted corridor FPS.  I know some say that lack of innovation is threatening to kill the games industry
column21: but I'd rather have a tried and true PC port of a formula we all know and love instead of an attempt to blend epic with mediocre.\n5/10"

reviewText: It's nothing like the other previous titles, not even close. I would rather have played fires of liberation if I still had my 360. The game has a  boring, no feeling of accomplishment story with heavily scripted battle system. The dog fight systems is sometimes disorienting  and in some levels it needs to be done in order to advance. You will sometimes fire lots of missles on an enemy plane hitting it multiple times and it would still be up. So will be stuck in some cases why is that plane not going down. I wish they would have added a solo wing fight instead of this dog fight system. The AC-130 and Apache missions felt call of dutyish and added nothing exciting to the game. Throughout the whole game I only wanted to see if I could spot Kei in the background. Buy it not out of curiousity for flight sims or if you're a fan of the series. Only buy it if you stole money from a friend who betrayed you. Then after giving them the game as a gift showing what you wasted their money on.

reviewText:
A seriously terrible game. Ignoring the trite, jingoistic, racist narrative: the gameplay consists of on-rails segments that are heavily scripted; there are only a few missions for each type of aircraft (bomber/fighter/heli); in-mission enemy aircraft do not fly into the area--they spawn out of nothing right beside you; there's very little SP content--once you finish the campaign, that's it. No reason to re-play missions, no free flight option, no way to set up your own dogfights, etc., etc.

Extremely terrible game.

And to cap it all off, there's no way to exit the game in-mission (and these tedious Call-of-Duty-inspired mission can be upwards of 40 minutes long) so to escape this putrid rubbish you have to alt+tab out to close the program, or manually cut the process. Yikes.
