reviewText:
This is NOT a recommendation. This is a warning.
Not only is this game a waste of money, but also an extreme waste of time. Due to my computer being more powerful than the consoles it was designed for, the game speed was accellerated to twice the speed viewed in the trailers. I had to stall out my plane just to be able to fly under the speed of light.

The controls are VERY clunky and un-coordinated. Inability to destroy fighters without going into dogfight mode is aggrovating. Dogfight mode being entirely an on-rails experience is rather disgusting. Enemy aircraft can trick you into a dive then veer 90 degrees to both lose you and make you run into the ground.

All in all, this is by far the single worst game I have ever played and didn't even get through the first level without wanting to pull the eject levers.
It's CoD in the air. Save your money. Go play a classic Ace Combat game.

(NOTE: Installation and Setup is an even worse ordeal. You have to set up an XBOX LIVE ACCOUNT to play! WTF!!! How does that make sense?!?!)

reviewText:
So, here I am, at the end of the game so I can finally write a review. I still haven't beaten it, but i'll get to that in a second. I love the Ace Combat games. I played many of the other Ace Combat games and this one remains fairly true to the series. I don't care much for the helicopter scenes, but the AC-130 and B2 missions are pretty cool. The graphics are fine and the gameplay itself is good.....overall.
So, why a negative review?
Because of DFM, dog fighting mode. The concept itself is a neat idea, but it doesn't work in reality. But is something like that really worth a negative review?
Spoiler*****


Yes, god yes, it is so worth a negative review. At the end of the game you must fight a boss who is invincible. Not invincible hard, LITERALLY invincible. Missles LITTERALLY appear out of thin air and start flying at you in AND out of DFM while you try to shoot the boss down. It's a timed event and it's stupid. I don't know how many times I have repeated the final mission just to try and kill the final boss, but I end up dying just before the end of my timed invincible boss event. I'm giving it a negative review solely because of this right here. This moment is one of the most frustrating in gaming I have ever played and I don't know that I will ever have the patience to beat the final boss.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I love the Ace Combat series, it has always been a good blend between sim and arcade. I feel this latest iteration the series has leaned much more towards arcade. My biggest complaint is toward the dog-fighting mechanic. Yes, it makes for great cinematic but it is often too difficult to really see what is going on and the controls only makes it worse. I have tried playing with a controller and flight stick, neither feel great for this game.\n\nTypically I would just ignore this “feature” altogether, however, you can't. The game forces you into these cinematic dogs fights and certain enemies cannot be shot down unless in dog-fighting mode. The entire thing just feels “off” to me in a modern aerial combat. Don't get me wrong, I don't love the Ace Combat series for it's realism, I love it for it uniqueness and story. I loved the crazy and sometimes frustrating boss battles. I love the characters and stories it told. The game could be dull at times but I enjoyed just flying around. Unfortunately, in their attempt to make something new and interesting, to me, it just feels like a series of gimmicks.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I owned AC6 on Xbox 360 and had a great time with that game. Unfortunately, AC:AH feels like a terrible port of a mediocre AC game.

The fun jet fighter elements of this game are obscured by frustrating and boring helicopter missions and extremely clunky controls (and I'm playing with a Xbox 360 controller). I was expecting at least 90% of the missions to be in a fighter jet. 2 of the first ~4 missions are in a helecopter.

That said, I did enjoy some parts of the game. Dogfight Mode (DFM) is a fun aspect of flight missions where your perspective is soft-locked onto your nearby target, and you have to maneuver your camera to get a quick missile hit. It's like a mini-game within the mission. This adds to the intensity of the game.

I bought the game because I was desperate for an AC experience, but this has been a major let down. Fortunately I got it for super cheap from humble bundle. Otherwise, I would be really upset.

This game is NOT worth full retail price. If you're reallllly desperate for a jet fighter game and this has a deep discount (<$5), it's probably worth it. Otherwise, try to find some other jet games.

reviewText:
Apparently physics is overrated.

Don't get me wrong. I know I am not playing DCS or BMS. And the normal gameplay (at least the aircraft part) is fine (I mean, I did use high yo-yo on some of the enemies). But that damn 'Dog Fight mode', holy ♥♥♥♥ was it bad. Also, apparently enemy planes (and sometimes their missile... hell, all of the missiles in this game) don't follow laws of physics.

Also, I swear those planes are made of mithril or something.

Did I mention that Dogfight Mode is horrible? And the enemy sometimes pulls ♥♥♥♥ that are actually physically impossible?

Yeah, unless you want to see a Kisaragi Chihaya Mudhen (ku!) CCIP dive-bomb (as in literally 70 degree dive kek) the ♥♥♥♥ out of people for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, don't buy it (especially not at full price).

reviewText:
For the price of a pint i'm not going to be too harsh on this game. Graphics are good, and the gamplay smooth. They get a pat on the back for the effort of adding a story line, even if they don't get one for the storyline itself. I get what they were trying to do with the gameplay, but i think the overly complicated control system gets in the way.

Its not a flight sim, keep it simple.

Pressing buttons at instructed intervals to perform 'random' tricks makes the whole thing feel to scripted and rather than pulling you in, adds as a constant reminder to how odd and detached the flight controls really are. The default helicopter controls are a crime against gaming! Everyone knows pushing forward on the stick dips the nose, you shouldnt have to set this crap up yourself! BAD PROGRAMMER, BAD BOY, NAUGHTY! probably about 10 which may explain how they never saw a single episode of Airwolf.

Overall, its well worth its bargain bin price and some may love the arcade style. Also, at least that dusty old joystick will get a bit of use, even if it is only for a few hours. Recommend this game?.....Hmmm, thats a bit strong. A definate maybe, but it the absence of a middle button, its really gotta be a 'No'.

reviewText:
The only Ace Combat game to be properly released on PC and it is the worst game in the series.
It ♥♥♥♥♥ on the old games by adding real world locations, helicopter missions, giving the faceless pilot not only a face but also a voice which happens to be a stereotypical American white guy.

The planes are still as good as ever, I can say that with absolute certainty. The F22/A Raptor makes a glorious return and looks and feels amazing. The overall quality in graphics is nice, a definiate improvement over the 2D textures that the older PS2 games had.

Oh here we go, the helicopter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This is by far the biggest problem in the game. They are boring and lobrious. Helicopters are slow, awkward to control and don't feel as satisfying when you control them. Like when you shoot another plane down in a plane, it's fast moving, you have skill in that. In a helicopter, you move so slow and aim so easily it is a joke. They are filler missions which pad the game more than they should.

There are other benefits though, mid-level check points. A long overdue feature. Nothing more annoying than playing Whiskey Corridor only to die about 1 minute from the end because you get rekted by an AA gun you neglected to see. Dog Fight Mode (DFM) was an interesting concept as well, but felt poorly integrated. A few times after exited that mode because I downed the enemy I crashed into a wall/floor because of the exiting angle. Enemies in this mode also seem to take about 50x more missiles to take out, which makes no sense at all. Also, planes now bleed all over your screen when you kill them.

Music in this game is also pretty lame in comprassion to the others. Megalith Agnus Dei, Zero both classic music from the games. Even Sea of Chaos from AC Unsung War is memoriable. I can't even name one track from this game.
The game is only not recommended because I am a ♥♥♥♥ing AC fan and it shocks me this was released.

ALSO DEAD MULTIPLAYER.

TL;DR

Would I recommend this game? To a new player, yes. Someone who has no idea of the past games it will be okay to play if you like flight sims. Buy it on sale though. It isn't worth the £10 they want to charge. It goes on sale for like £2.50 sometimes. Still a rip off, but a bit better.

For a classic AC player? No. This game ♥♥♥♥♥ on the game series you love.

reviewText:
This is merely just a spin-off Ace Combat with some elements featured such as Close Range Assault (DFM and ASM) that mostly obligatory thus kinda ruins the freedom of the dogfight, aircraft usage restrictions on several missions, and the lack of the emphasized drama appeared on past titles (most of those featured superb anime-styled storylines that distinguish Ace Combat from most of other combat flight series ) makes it very detached from the entire series.

The good thing about this that it has good graphics, sounds, and still fun gameplay even though some features mentioned above kinda ruins it. The flight dynamics are good for the game of this genre. It also has a fair amount of playable aircrafts to choose.

Since I've played most of Ace Combat games in the series before, I found this one kinda disappointing if compared to the other titles in the series, but still enjoyable. Still, I personally think it's a good thing there's an Ace Combat game on PC officially (although the spin-off one) remembering there haven't been any Ace Combat games on PC officially before. Maybe someday there'll be another Ace Combat game on PC that will remain faithful to its Strangereal saga.

In general, I'd still recommend this to those who enjoy arcade combat flight genre in general. But if you're an avid Ace Combat fan who trully miss and wants the iconic Strangereal elements in terms of story, atmosphere, and gameplay-feels from AC1,2,3,04,5,Zero, X, and 6, then maybe this game isn't for you.

reviewText:
FIrst off let me say that if you have 5 screens, dual flight sticks and a hydraulic chair to simulate cockpit movement, then this game is not for you. If you do however have a usb controller, a set of headphones and are looking for some arcade fun then this IS for you.

You'll notice some reviews bag the game for not being true to the franchise or that the voice acting is terrible (both true) but at the end of the day it's an airforce combat game where you fly different vehicles, all of which provide great variety.

The game can also be quite challenging at times, having multiple hostiles locked onto you and dodging half a dozen missles at a time will keep your thumbs dancing. There's also some nice cinematics when dog fighting through city buildings, you get the sense of danger as the buildings loom large over you.

Some of the negatives include flat textures, rubber banding by the AI and surprisingly a lack of ammunition in some missions, including the Apache levels, as well as the aforementioned franchise deviation and voice acting.

But if you can look past these rather small flaws you'll enjoy a fun game with great replay value (and co-op missions).

Maybe wait for sales before buying though.

reviewText:
TLDR: Bad PC port, don't buy.

Game can't handle a HOTAS, especially not in combination with foot pedals.

It could easily be fixed with settings for deadzones, as most games have, this game however does not. Ends up with you having constant inputs all over the place, good luck trying to change your settings when the menus keeps scrolling because you have imputs from all over the place.

Also, the game won't let you barrel roll on the standard settings, you need to go into settings, controls and change from their default setting optimum" to the setting "original" to even be able to roll your plane all the way around. Took a while to figure out."

reviewText: This game will definitely appeal to certain people...but I'm not one of them. It is, overall, a pretty braindead game that you will never really put much thought into. Dogfights, though visually appealing, aren't strategic in any way. No interesting story or characters to speak of. The overall experience felt like a bif explosive rollercoaster that was designed for me to win rather than for me to think my way through an actual challenge (think singleplayer Call of Duty in the air). I'm no grapgics junkie, but the ground textures were the absolute worse I've seen in any case of recent memory. A few trees and buildings are actually rendered in 3D over a mesh, but the rest of the world is a extremely low res flat texture laid out on the floor like a newspaper. Homeless people sleep on prettier things than this. This is not a game where you will want to fly very close to the ground...ever. If mindless, Japanese military-wannabe games is your thing then you'll enjoy it. I personally wish I could have the time I spent on this back.

reviewText:
This is NOT a recommendation. This is a warning.
Not only is this game a waste of money, but also an extreme waste of time. Due to my computer being more powerful than the consoles it was designed for, the game speed was accellerated to twice the speed viewed in the trailers. I had to stall out my plane just to be able to fly under the speed of light.

The controls are VERY clunky and un-coordinated. Inability to destroy fighters without going into dogfight mode is aggrovating. Dogfight mode being entirely an on-rails experience is rather disgusting. Enemy aircraft can trick you into a dive then veer 90 degrees to both lose you and make you run into the ground.

All in all, this is by far the single worst game I have ever played and didn't even get through the first level without wanting to pull the eject levers.
It's CoD in the air. Save your money. Go play a classic Ace Combat game.

(NOTE: Installation and Setup is an even worse ordeal. You have to set up an XBOX LIVE ACCOUNT to play! WTF!!! How does that make sense?!?!)

reviewText:
Long story short, tl’dr version? It’s a completely sub-average action game that has a few high moments but also has some really low ones evening it out. If you can get it on sale then it’s probably worth your time, but at full price I can’t recommend it. Also as I always like to mention when reviewing a game in this genre, Ace Combat is an ARCADE flight game, meaning it’s not a hyper-realistic flight-sim but instead an action game in the air which is something I see getting confused about a lot.

Much longer version? Assault Horizon isn’t a horrible game, and if you enjoy the arcade flight genre you’ll likely get at least one playthrough out of it. That said it’s definitely one if not the weakest entry in the Ace Combat series and some really weird design decisions keep it from being infinitely replayable like its forbearers.  Positives include some attractive if not top-of-the-line visuals, good voice work, and a really strong score.

But that’s where the praise ends really and it can’t make up for what the game’s lacking, and some really atrocious gameplay mechanics. First-and-foremost is the big elephant in the room that every review touches on, the automated dogfighting mode (DFM). Basically once you’ve gotten within shooting distance of an enemy you hit a key and the game pulls into a close-cam attack that has the computer automatically trailing the enemy, with you focusing on achieving lock-on.

I think I know what they were going for here. They wanted to create a more cinematic experience allowing you to go through all sorts of tight turns and close-ground fly-bys that just aren’t possible for most players. But in actuality what you get is a system that takes 90% of the gameplay out of your hands, and is buggy to boot. Now I can hear what you’re saying, “Don’t use it then”, which I would love to do but the game forces you to make use of it.

Enemy planes are capable of pulling impossible moves (not in a thrust vectoring way, in a literally turns 180 on the spot way that I’m pretty sure is a straight out bug) that absolutely require the use of this mode as trailing enemies, and switching between them is sluggish in manual. To make matters worse things get really…obvious as the max speed of the planes you fly increases. If your plane is faster than the enemies you enter a jumpy, stilted slide-show as your plane forcibly slows down so that you don’t go flying past the enemy making the fact that the system is totally on-rails really blatant. I’m not averse to making the experience more cinematic and entertaining, but it shouldn’t sacrifice gameplay in the process. You also have a similar process for ground assaults and bombing runs but they’re a little less on-rails making them bearable.

Additionally perhaps about 1/3 of the game isn’t even in a plane. Several large parts or entire missions are from the perspective of a helicopter pilot or the door gunner. Another misguided attempt at expanding the experience but as all these missions are little more than “Hold mouse to win” it falls short. In particular the gunner levels require no skill as you only have to hit in the general vicinity of an enemy to kill them.

Lastly there’s the story that’s gotten a lot of flak from longtime fans, personally I can see it from both ways but I do think it’s one of the weaker ones. On one hand they ditched the somewhat fantastical Ace-world where unrealistic super-weapons and corny but enjoyable characters were the norm for a more stock story set in the “real” world. At the same time there are the makings of a traditional Aces story.  Impossibly skilled protagonist, betrayal, crazy over-the-top unlikely war that only you can solve, etc. It’s all here and on occasion when the situations right and the music kicks in you get those warm waves of nostalgia. But the gameplays too broken and the whole “set in the real world” thing makes it hard to buy.

The reason AC could get away with those silly stories was because it took place in a world where technology was different than ours, and where there were about a billion countries all vying for control, regularly splintering into new countries resulting in constant battles. It wasn’t realistic per-se but it took place in its own little bubble world that made things easier to digest. When you try to tack those same rules and morals on to the world as it exists the ridiculousness of the situation starts to shine through and become harder to enjoy. It’s not without its moments but it also limits the story. Because it takes place in the real world, or some approximation of it, that means we also don’t get any super planes/vehicles/weapons or any of the other crazy stuff AC liked to throw at you. So you’re stuck somewhere between the real and the crazy but since it can’t go full bore either way it’s just left dangling in limbo.

So, yeah, if you liked previous Ace Combats or just action games in general and can pick this up on the cheap then you’ll get your 6-hours-or-so of enjoyment out of it. But too many issues plague it to make it more than a passing fling you’ll quickly abandon for something else. My time with the game wasn’t totally unenjoyable but if I hadn’t picked it up on sale I’m not sure I would feel so forgiving.

reviewText:
What a shame.

In an attempt to revitalize a series that didn't really need it, Namco and Project Aces wound up just dumbing it down and ripping out any charm it had in the process. The game certainly looks quite nice, it is too bad you won't get to control it half the time you're playing.

The game seems intent on forcing you to watch Michael Bay-esque explosion and destruction setpieces, through the use of a new feature" called Dog Fight Mode. I'm not sure what the intent was here
date: but what they did was made roughly half of the enemy fighter pilots in the game nearly impossible to shoot down by giving them an infinite amount of flares that recharge instantly
recommended: an apparent invulnerability to gun fire
hoursPlayed: and twitchy flight patterns that their aircraft should not be capable of performing.\n\nAll that is to force you to activate Dog Fight Mode
voteText: a glorified Quick Time Event. It takes control away from the player (pretty much always a sign of a bad game design idea) and instead lets you nudge the plane around slightly on a preset path
helpfulPercent: with the goal of firing missiles when a circle turns red and lining up the gun sight with the enemy. It feels incredibly janky and unsatisfying.\n\nEven then
votesHelpful: the game will pull impossible stunts and prevent you from killing the enemy jet until you fly past whatever dumb falling crane or explosion they want you to see. Because god forbid we have these things trigger naturally
votesTotal: that might actually be satisfying for the player. No instead the developers decide you have to see THIS exact sequence of events EXACTLY like this.\n\nRather than having a goofy flight game with solid mechanics in an absurd setting
votesFunny: they went with a boring real world setting and broke the mechanics so they could shoehorn in an unwanted feature that does nothing but effectively force you to view cutscenes. I was hoping that I would be able to avoid using DFM entirely

reviewText: If you thought Ace Combat 2 - 6 were fun... you should save your money because this game throws the entire evolution of the series out the window and replaces it with Quicktime events and automated dogfighting.  Missions have no briefings and no choice of strategies, and therefore no context to what you are doing.  There are no wing leader commands.  Battles are boring and tedious because you must kill a majority of enemies using DFM.  I never needed DFM to dogfight before so It's a very confusing thing to not only add... but to make a requirement.  The graphics are pretty good but sadly the immersion is destroyed by the in your face" stylings of the game.  If you know who Mobius 1 is

If you want Ace Combat go turn on your PS2. This is not Ace Combat.

reviewText:
Pros:
Soundtrack is solid. Not the best IMO of the AC series, but better than most other games soundtrack. Features a nice blend of orchestra, rock, and electronic, but doesn't sit as well as other orchestra AC soundtracks. Proably becuase of the electronic sounds.
Lots of eye candy. First couple missions feel really damn cool.
Dog Fight Mode(DFM) is a cool idea(at first)

Cons:
DFM gets old fast, especially since there are tons of situations where it is forced on the player.
A lot of the DFM battles are actually scripted, and prevent a plane from being shot down until they do something (like fire a missle at a building)
The helicopter missions need a lot of work, The AC-130 mission seems like a re-text of a mission in COD4. Bomber mission is ok, but doens't bring much to the table.
Aircraft selection is restricted based off of the mission. Sorry its a multi-role mission, you can't fly the Su-33.
No wingman or allied control.
Due to the sheer number of DFM and ASM moments(think DFM but for ground targets), the game feels like its on rails.

If your a fan of previous AC games, I would recommend letting this one go. I wouldn't pay more than like 10 dollars for it. DFM and the sheer amount of eye candy the game offers are really cool for about 3 missions.  I find myself playing a select set of 3 missions, and its mainly for the soundtrack.

Proably the single most annoying thing is how forced the DFM and ASM modes are. Some planes will take infinite damage unitl you start DFM, in which case they will only be shot down after a particular event occurs(ie, a bomber will not be destroyed until you start DFM with it and it is also .3 miles from its target)

If your new to the series, I would recommend starting on one of the 3 AC's for the PS2 or AC6 for the Xbox-360.

reviewText:
As a standalone game this game is a decently fun title with some shining moments.

But as an Ace Combat, its an Insult to the franchise.
+ Music if good
+ Get almost all DLC from consoles free in this version
+ New mechanic is fresh and innovative
- To many scripted sequences
- No interesting Superweapons, just a nuke instead of flying fortresses and railguns
- Generic America vs Russia storyline instead
- DFM is nearly always needed
- DFM in multiplayer is extremely laggy
- Helicopter missions and on rails shooter elements aren't the most fun or enjoyable

reviewText:
Reviewed in Oct. 29, 2011 at...

http://that-riyadh-gamer.blogspot.com/2011/10/review-ace-combat-assault-horizon.html

“Make Metal Bleed” as the back cover of the game said

If you ask me what’s my best jet fighting simulation game i’ve played in my life, that would be Ace Combat series. I played most of them since the first one on PS1. All my life, i never found another game that can par with NAMCOs’ masterpeice.

After a long wait for consoles since Ace Combat 6, it’s back with agressiveness pushing away other games that tried to challenge one of NAMCOs’ pride and asset.

Though did it delivered well? We shall see as i share my thoughts on the game.

Presentation:

“Modern Warfare in the sky”

The set up is now mentioned in actual world locations, mentioning from previous trailers are Miami, African locations and many more. Surely the game won’t be complete without a storyline and now it’s been aided by a New York Times bestselling military author Jim DeFelice and shaped a story about Lt. Colonel William Bishop from the Warwolf Flight Squadron and his quest to stop a Russian terrorist named Col. Markov “Akula” who has a weapon that can blow up pretty much a city. Unlike the previous and traditional Ace’s direct mission briefing then take off segment, they added some QTE (Quick Time Event) elements for you to react while off the plane (Heavy Rain-ish) which basically pointless for me to be honest. But gladly the phasing is fast & it won’t take long till you get on a mission. It’s a new gesture from the game and also trying other weaponries and aircrafts. Let’s say aside from flying planes, one of them is you can fly an AH-64D Apache Longbow, a gunner on MH-60 Black Hawk and other planes with different functions depending on the given mission. So basically it’s a different curve but it’s still a welcomed add on.

Graphics:

There are no traces to disappoint the game in terms of visuals. The textures on a blown enemy aircraft is spot on, however I laughed when I saw a blown pilot wasn’t ripped to shreds as I blew his plane sky high. But I guess to avoid being flagged as a bloody game perhaps. But none the less, seeing a shattered plane gives you the sense of sweet victory after taking them down on plane after the other.

Gameplay:

You fly a plane & blow some stuff up, simple? Well it used to be like that but the new installment has some treats to keep you occupied for a bit by flying attack choppers, bombers and also a gunner. Though the main meat of the game is to be the Ace in the air and fly planes with different specs and specialties for each given mission. The new main element of the game is the Close-range assault “Dogfight mode”. It can be activated when you’re close enough to an enemy plane; there, the controls will turn into a semi automatic tailing enemy planes (which is a bit silly for me but it made up by taking control on a close range attack) and stick with them as long as you can till you destroy them in mid-air, that way you will feel the sense of satisfaction after each kill. However there are two kinds of control mode whereas semi auto pilot “Optimum” for those who are new in the genre (which I don’t like to use) & the “Original” mode for those who are veterans (like me) on the game that will let you fully control your plane and do as many barrel rolls as you pleased.

Each plane has their own special weapons and class whether a bomber, an air-to-air or both. There are tons of planes to choose from and that will also please the fans and keep them busy searching for their favorite plan/s (where are my Su planes from the start of the game!!!).

Aside from the single player, the multiplayer is back with co-op or a death match for all 16 players and plane customizations.

In co-op mode, you can team up with a trusted buddy while on 16 multiplayer, first there’s Capital Conquest where each team has a group base to protect and destroy the other team’s base; there’s also Domination where you capture ground installations and lastly there’s the classic deathmatch where it’s more intense than the single player by taking down a real player to see who dominates the skies. So basically the other half of the fun lies in the multiplayer.

Audio:

In terms of voice acting, it’s pretty stiff which sometimes feel like the character’s movement didn’t blend well to the voice acting. I also found out that the sound quality wasn’t that epic enough for my 5.1 surround sound headset which I found that the music was louder than rest so I had to adjust the volumes. But on the brighter side, its well done in terms of explosions, weapons and epic OST which has a mixed of Rock Metal & Orchestra feel to it; plus a one of their track called “Rush” gave me Goosebumps whenever I hear the guitar solo.

Overall:

Ace Combat: Assault Horizon is actually a good game but not as great as Ace Combat 5 for me. The gameplay, graphics, OST are there but the storyline fell short and wasn’t as epic as I experienced in AC5s' “The Journey home” song which the game also represents “world peace” from two giant fictional country fighting earch other that almost made a world war. But none the less, this game is a welcomed from its genre; Project ACES still is untouchable and cannot be compared when it comes to making a good arcade jet fighting simulator game. So if you ask me again what’s my favorite fighting simulation game? I’d still say NAMCOs’ Ace Combat series and this will be one of them but the best of them. This will be welcomed for young aces with the help of putting a modern feel to it; and for the fan of the genre, go get it, it's worth the wait and you can't find anything better than Ace Combat.


Pro(s)

Intense new Dog fight system

Awesome Multiplayer

Breath taking OST

Using other air craft

Faster phased air combat in the series


Con(s)

You can forget about the storyline

A few missions doesn’t feel right

Pointless off battle interactions at times

Pointless QTEs

reviewText:
I really had high hopes for this game. I waited until it was on sale for half the price (I believe $20~25) and purchased it. The story is, as expected, complete garbage. The twist was more predictable than putting water in the freezer for ice cubes. It was clearly written by someone who should stick to the cheesy anime pornos rather than serious war stories.

Speaking of serious war stories, why are Russians always evil? Why can't it be America for once? We're evil, just look at our drone strikes and Snowden and!..... Okay, getting ahead of myself.

Anyway, this was the first jet" game that I got that tried something new other than playing as a camera w/ turrets (a UAV) rather than a jet: A chopper. Lemme tell you: I wish it didn't. THe worse parts of this game are the chopper sections and they are a good chunk.

Avoid this one
date: go get HAWX 1 instead. It's cheaper and has more dog fights."

Totally regretting my purchase, thanks Japan

reviewText:
Ace Combat Assault Horizon is actually better than what people say it is.  Although the storyline isn't as clear as titles such as Ace Combat 6: Fires of Liberation, it is still pretty decent for a video game.

The gameplay mechanics are also great.  The dogfight mode really gets me into the game and makes me really focus hard on what I am trying to do.  Just like the other Ace Combat titles, I love how you have a special weapon and a regular one, just to help you out in fast-paced dogfights or trying to kill multiple enemies at once.

The graphics are just wonderful.  There is not much to be said with that, but I think that lots of people can agree the graphics are very well-done.

One thing I do not like about it is how there aren't very many missions.  I completed the game very quickly, which isn't really a good thing.  If there aren't that many missions, I think they should at least have something else to make you play it a little more.  The multiplayer was made for probably this reason, but have you found sessions that often?

If you do not have time to read all of this, I'll give you the pros and cons right here.

Pros:
Great mechanics
Great graphics
Great missions

Cons:
Very short game
Not many/no people are on multiplayer a lot of times

Overall, I really like the game, and I think it stands next to my favorites in the Ace Combat series.

reviewText: I did't really get into this game. The last Ace Combat I played was 04: Shattered Skies on PS2. That game was fantastic, and I was thinking that this one would be similar. But, sadly, I was wrong. The Dog Fight mechanic in this game turns what should be adrenaline-pumping, fast-paced flying action into simple point-and-click gameplay. Simply engage Dog Fight mode, and your plane does almost all the flying for you. Just lock onto an enemy with your rockets or machine gun and let loose. I got an achievement where you fly below a falling chimney, and didn't even realize I did it because the Dog Fight mode did all the flying for me. What's worse is that there are some enemies that can only be shot down this way. And what's EVEN worse is that the story can only be advanced with dog fighting in some instances. I normally don't give a game a bad review based solely on one flaw of the game, but this flaw is so ridiculously massive and constant that it just stopped me from enjoying the game. It's got great graphics, though.

reviewText:
Let me state I've already played and completed this game when it initially came out on the xbox 360. I've always been an ace combat fan so I'll admit to some bias in that regard, along with a love of military aircraft in general.

That said, this itiration of the Ace Combat series, while fun, full of adrenaline, and still top notch in visual quality as you'd expect, I still felt the new Dog Fighting mechanic took away from some of the imersion.

In previous titles, dog fighting was as you'd imagine, difficult. Trying to follow your target while staying in range for your main gun and leading the target so you actually hit. While at the same time making sure you did not crash into anything. This, obviously takes some skill and practice, which I felt was a good challenge to the game.

Assault Horizon however takes the burden of piloting and has you focus more on the target. Now it's a matter of making sure your crosshair is on target for your main gun or missles (whichever you prefer) and the plane is essentially on auto pilot after the target. You can change your pitch and angle, sure, but you are certainly only following the target aircraft.

This was more a design decision to add cinematic fluff than anything else. That hollywood sequence of flying just underneath a crane while at Mach 2 is undeniably impressive and enjoyable for most. But after repeated intervals, it begins to feel cheapened.

This is certainly a good game for those new to the flight combat sim, or new to Ace Combat in general to get a feel for series. While I wish they kept the old dog fighting mechanics in this, it does allow for a lot of 'wow' moments when you do pull them off.

reviewText:
Been a huge fan of the Ace Combat Series on the PS2. When I heard this coming out, and saw it (Got it on sale a while back) I was super excited! HD AC sounds fantastic!
Though shortly after beginning to play, I found myself feeling let down.
One of the biggest let downs was the DFM (Dog-Fight Mode) and what it does is cause your plane to vaguely trail the enemy, and allow you chances to shoot at it crom closer up. While it sounds interesting, it really felt like I wasn't doing much. Just occaisionally adjusting my angle and firing over and over. That was only one.
To me, the Ace Combat series captured me with the story. That was my favorite part. The story here is somwehat cliche in my opinion, and lacks the immersion I would get with other titles.

All in all, even though I wouldn't recomend this came (Unless it was on sale for DIRT cheap) I still find myself coming back to it. I don't know why however.

reviewText: This might be fine for someone who just wants an air combat game to play, but if you're a fan of the older AC titles like AC04 this just isn't for you.\n\nSeveral major elements have been changed for jets: Your machine guns never run out of ammo, and neither do your missiles, they simply have a cooldown period. There's also a new chase" mechanic which locks you onto an enemy and autopilots you around
date: making aiming your only concern in a dogfight. It's basically rail shooter mode. Not only is this boring and unchallenging
recommended: but it also looks ridiculous as you weave between buildings and oil rigs at mach two. Use of this mechanic is optional against most enemies
hoursPlayed:
but certain VIP targets force you to use it in order to take them down.

The helicopter missions come in two flavors: awkwardly controlled attack helo and boring rail shooter transport helo. There are also gunship rail shooter missions straight out of CoD.

Overall everything feels very scripted like a CoD game and there isn't a lot of room for stages to play out differently when you replay them. There's no tension because you never run out of ammo
voteText: and there's no challenge because of the autopiloting chase system.\n\nIf you're a long-time AC fan like me you'll probably hate this game. If you still buy CoD games then this is for you."

reviewText:
Kick the tires and light the fires!  While I'm not overly fond of making this a real-world gritty story in a departure from the fully established world of the resst of the Ace Combat series, I stil think this is one of the most fun gaming experiences you can have.  It's Project Gotham for airplanes, just enough realism and detail for those with an appreciative eye for military hardware but arcade simplicity and bombastic presentation that keep it well clear of inaccessable, monolithic sims like Falcon 4.0 and its ilk.

Dogfight and Airstrike modes are a mixed bag, and may prove more enjoyable against human opposition than AI (where it can just be a blurry frustration), but there's still no flight game that I've played that conveys the adrenaline and speed of sitting in half a billion dollars of cutting edge hardware going past the speed of sound while absolutely everything else in the sky wants you dead.

This is Top Gun.  This is Iron Eagle.  This IS the highway to the Danger Zone and if you ever asked for Goose to talk to you then you owe it to yourself to give it a go.

Plus Idolm@ster skins.  Nice.

reviewText:
This game has too many flaws in it to be enjoyable.  This game isn't worthy of the title of Ace Combat.  I want to go in with an open mind but it just has terrible game mechanics.  From planes performing impossible moves to the dog fight not engaging at the correct time, this game can aggrivate even the most hardcore veterans of the Ace Combat series.  The development crew must have been a bunch of guys who grew up with COD and wanted to emulate it to the letter, with bad story telling and just making certain that there is an explosion every 3 seconds.

The story could have been a lot better, but the writers decided to go with the most severly ADD pilot I have ever met and to have no depth with character development.  They also wanted to go for the whole Russia is bad theme that COD has beaten to death and then some.  I mean I get the fact that from the Cold War, Russia has never got rid of their stigma of being evil, but I mean come on, lets see something more interesting.  The main villian of the series lacks a true motive for what he is doing, and, personally, they really needed to expand his backstory.  I got to say it was pretty boring when the AC-130 level came into play, cause I was spoiled by how good COD's version was (I will say that that was my favorite level in COD).  You would think that a game producer who focuses just on aircraft would have a better grasp on this.  I will say that the helicopter missions were definitly interesting and a breath of fresh air, once you died 20 times just trying to get used to the new controls.

The gameplay mechanics are another point in the game that actually hurt it.  The dogfight mode is intersting, but annoying when you lockon a target and face an invincible fighter plane, because the producers want you to go through their house of explosions before you can take him out.  Also I have had this little problem affect me multiple times, I will be in the dogfight mode and the enemy plane nose-dives into the ground, and you would think that that is one less plane I have to worry about. Wrong, because your plane will also quickly follow suit and explode, just because dogfight wants you to have the nose of your aircraft so far up the enemies exhaust, that you could just pull the fuel lines, that you also share the fate due to bad AI pathing.  Also while the cinematic following of the missles is pretty cool, it just detracts from the game and causes you to sit in your chair for an extra 5 seconds, while you could be shooting down the other guys who is in front of you.  Once you come out of it 9 times out of 10, they have escaped.  Also the quicktime events are dumb, they offer no, I repeat no, effect on the game, but their are about 3 out of 20-something quicktime events that will make you fail a mission.

The last major problem I had is that the game isn't that hard.  Changing the difficulty isn't really a test of your skill, like having less ammunition or the AI being smarter, rather it's just how much more that the AI can defy physics and perform outragious moves.  One example is the final dog fight and it has to be done in dogfight mode.  If you break dog fight with the enemy, then the enemy can perform some weird 360-180 backflip, with a double axial from hell and be right on your rear.  Sure it makes it harder but it is just something that isn't that fun to deal with.

The good thing about this game is the normal dogfighting, not that stupid lockon behind them crap.  It was a blast to relive the old system of using the IFF to track down targets and just shoot them down.  That was a method that proved your worth in the old games, where if you couldn't manually track behind your targets and tack them out with missles of guns, you were dead.

If you are a new flyer to the Ace Combat series and were either turned off or interested in the series, I recommend that you get a ps2 and play Ace Combat 5 and/or Ace Combat 0.  The reason is simple, the Ace Combat series is hands down one of the best jet fighter sims out there, and this version was just a disgrace.  Now maybe I'm a guy who just enjoys living in the past, but I can tell you that this game had potential but terrible execution.

Keep those skies clear.

(PS I don't like to put spoliers in my reviews, so I am unable to explain, in this already long review, certain key elements in the story that are just bad.  Also I don't really play multiplayer due to internet problems.  So my review is focused towards those who enjoy the campagin of games.)

reviewText: This game is an abomination. First sin- story lost all of the old cheese and replaced it with real world cookie cutter characters. Second sin - the helicopter missions are awful, controls like a pig and the engine is not designed for rendering ground objects at close distances at all; travel back in time to 1999 graphics. Third, ultimate and unforgivable sin - the game insists on taking away control of the plane constantly. It forces you to use the Dogfighting Mode to fight tougher opponents, essentially changing it to an on-rails shooter with you being able to control aiming and the camera going crazy. It was supposed to be dynamic, but instead is chaotic and aggravating. I can't remember ever feeling offended by a game. This game is an abomination.

reviewText:
Ace Combat with PC frames is RIDICULOUSLY GOOD.
Since you can turn the dial up to pretty damn high levels on the framerate side, there's pretty smooth flying, Fox.
Would still recommend playing with a gamepad, though it's easy enough played with keyboard and mouse. Planes are strictly keyboard based, helichoppers are mouse and keyboard combo, side gunner is strictly mouse and can be likened to a point and click adventure.
IT SHOULD REALLY BE SAID however that Assault Horizon is not Ace Combat as those familiar with the series would remember it as. While the helicopters are neat (albeit limited) and planes are still the focus, it's a story mode with talking protags and a very arcadey DFM (DogFight Mode) system. Incredibly cinematic, and I enjoy it personally, but it's not the good ol' method of taking out the baddies.
Still, if you've tried AC:AH already, the PC version is the one taking it to eleven.

reviewText: This game definitely falls short of what I have come to expect from the Ace Combat franchise. You are forced to use a no skill dogfight mode that only requires you keep you're target within a circle on the screen and fire missiles. There are a few levels, such as the helicopter gunner ones, that have you on rails" for the entire time. These are tedious and can't be completed until the action sequences run their course. It's also no longer set in a fictional world
date: which destroys the suspension of disbelief that made it so you don't question the unbelievably huge aerial battles. You are also given regenerative health on your plane
recommended: which means that if you take damage you can just play conservatively for a bit and not have to worry about being shot down. Overall

reviewText: With very little game time here, the only thing I have noticed so far that I don't like about this game vs previous Ace Combat titles, is the lack of aircraft free-maneuverability.  In every other title that I have played, you have the ability for barrel rolls, and other high-speed maneuvers that this title lacks.  That said, I really appreciate the high quality graphics, the way that aircraft fragment as they are being hit, etc.  Ace Combat continues to live up to their players' expectations, and are keeping me as an avid player.

reviewText:
A fantastic fighter jet simulator game with a much improved experience in my opinion from the early PlayStation days.

Pros & Cons

Pros:
+ The PC specs for running this game are good
+ Splendid picture quality
+ A decent soundtrack
+ New game modes (bomber, heli) such fun..
+ Has quite a few arcade elements from the previous games which gives the game that greatness from the early PlayStation days.

Cons:
- Using the chase" mode against targets can be slightly annoying and you are forced to use it is what makes that feature annoying.

I would especially recommend this game for the price when the steam sales are on

reviewText:
The challenge for any game like this is finding the ballance between sim and arcade.
This game is 110% arcade and 0% sim.
Does not suit me personaly, but might suit those who are chasing an arcade experience.

The first person parts are heavily scripted, to the point where all you can do is turn your head (using the keyboard and not mouse!), there is no freedom to walk at all.

reviewText: I'm usually not this harsh on most games but it is not even worth paying 5 bucks for this game in the current Steam Sale. It's a step backwards for the Ace Combat franchise in every possible way. The flight controls have been atrociously dumbed down and every plane has the same cartoonish feel. The combat system constantly forces you into annoying pre-scripted quick time sequences. The story boils down to cliche American bros fighting evil Russian terrorists who somehow have a super advanced air force. Oh and the graphics are horrible. It would be like Activison trying to make Call of Duty with Planes" and farming out the development to the most incompetent studio they could find."

reviewText:
This game has too many flaws in it to be enjoyable.  This game isn't worthy of the title of Ace Combat.  I want to go in with an open mind but it just has terrible game mechanics.  From planes performing impossible moves to the dog fight not engaging at the correct time, this game can aggrivate even the most hardcore veterans of the Ace Combat series.  The development crew must have been a bunch of guys who grew up with COD and wanted to emulate it to the letter, with bad story telling and just making certain that there is an explosion every 3 seconds.

The story could have been a lot better, but the writers decided to go with the most severly ADD pilot I have ever met and to have no depth with character development.  They also wanted to go for the whole Russia is bad theme that COD has beaten to death and then some.  I mean I get the fact that from the Cold War, Russia has never got rid of their stigma of being evil, but I mean come on, lets see something more interesting.  The main villian of the series lacks a true motive for what he is doing, and, personally, they really needed to expand his backstory.  I got to say it was pretty boring when the AC-130 level came into play, cause I was spoiled by how good COD's version was (I will say that that was my favorite level in COD).  You would think that a game producer who focuses just on aircraft would have a better grasp on this.  I will say that the helicopter missions were definitly interesting and a breath of fresh air, once you died 20 times just trying to get used to the new controls.

The gameplay mechanics are another point in the game that actually hurt it.  The dogfight mode is intersting, but annoying when you lockon a target and face an invincible fighter plane, because the producers want you to go through their house of explosions before you can take him out.  Also I have had this little problem affect me multiple times, I will be in the dogfight mode and the enemy plane nose-dives into the ground, and you would think that that is one less plane I have to worry about. Wrong, because your plane will also quickly follow suit and explode, just because dogfight wants you to have the nose of your aircraft so far up the enemies exhaust, that you could just pull the fuel lines, that you also share the fate due to bad AI pathing.  Also while the cinematic following of the missles is pretty cool, it just detracts from the game and causes you to sit in your chair for an extra 5 seconds, while you could be shooting down the other guys who is in front of you.  Once you come out of it 9 times out of 10, they have escaped.  Also the quicktime events are dumb, they offer no, I repeat no, effect on the game, but their are about 3 out of 20-something quicktime events that will make you fail a mission.

The last major problem I had is that the game isn't that hard.  Changing the difficulty isn't really a test of your skill, like having less ammunition or the AI being smarter, rather it's just how much more that the AI can defy physics and perform outragious moves.  One example is the final dog fight and it has to be done in dogfight mode.  If you break dog fight with the enemy, then the enemy can perform some weird 360-180 backflip, with a double axial from hell and be right on your rear.  Sure it makes it harder but it is just something that isn't that fun to deal with.

The good thing about this game is the normal dogfighting, not that stupid lockon behind them crap.  It was a blast to relive the old system of using the IFF to track down targets and just shoot them down.  That was a method that proved your worth in the old games, where if you couldn't manually track behind your targets and tack them out with missles of guns, you were dead.

If you are a new flyer to the Ace Combat series and were either turned off or interested in the series, I recommend that you get a ps2 and play Ace Combat 5 and/or Ace Combat 0.  The reason is simple, the Ace Combat series is hands down one of the best jet fighter sims out there, and this version was just a disgrace.  Now maybe I'm a guy who just enjoys living in the past, but I can tell you that this game had potential but terrible execution.

Keep those skies clear.

(PS I don't like to put spoliers in my reviews, so I am unable to explain, in this already long review, certain key elements in the story that are just bad.  Also I don't really play multiplayer due to internet problems.  So my review is focused towards those who enjoy the campagin of games.)

reviewText:
The story and characters are pretty cheesy and sometimes almost unbearable to watch/listen to.
The actual flying is fun but extremly arcady, it feels like one of these mecha animes where there are hundreds of missiles comming towards you. You also have 300+ missiles in a F22 Raptor.... Apperantly previous installments where set in fictional universes, it would seem to have been better that way.

Techinical:
The graphics are ok, a nice plus was that it recognized my triple scrreen setup with proper fov and placing the elements at the right locations. Some of the building textures on the map seemed a bit low res, which was evident in the chopper missions.
The controller configuration is difficult. My mouse had a way too low sensitivty.. one mousedrag was 15 degrees on screen in the chopper. The X52 Joystick/pedal was not recognized properly.

Multiplayer would find no sessions. Which i find somewhat hard to believe on a free weekend. Self hosted servers for the win!

I had fun for 10 hours playing the storyline. It being free it was ok.
